The '''South West Surrey by-election, 1984''' was a [[by-election|parliamentary by-election]] held on 3 May 1984 for the [[British House of Commons]] [[United Kingdom constituencies|constituency]] of [[South West Surrey (UK Parliament constituency)|South West Surrey]].
== Previous MP == The seat had become vacant on 10 March 1984. The constituency's [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] [[Member of Parliament]] (MP), [[Maurice Macmillan]], had died suddenly at the age of 63. He had recently acquired the [[courtesy title]] of Viscount Macmillan of Ovendon when his father (who would ultimately outlive him by nearly three years)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/december/29/newsid_2547000/2547307.stm |title=BBC ON THIS DAY | 29 | 1986: Harold Macmillan dies |publisher=BBC News |date=1998-12-29 |accessdate=2010-12-12}}</ref> was created the [[Earl of Stockton]] on 24 February 1984.
Maurice Macmillan was a Cabinet minister in [[Edward Heath]]'s government in the 1970s, as well as the son of former Conservative Prime Minister [[Harold Macmillan]], who was still alive when his son died. He had been South West Surrey's MP since the constituency was created for the [[United Kingdom general election, 1983|1983 general election]], having previously been MP for [[Farnham (UK Parliament constituency)|Farnham]] from [[United Kingdom general election, 1966|1966]]. Macmillan had first entered [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Parliament]] at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1955|1955 general election]] representing the constituency of [[Halifax (UK Parliament constituency)|Halifax]], but had lost his seat at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1964|1964 general election]].
== Candidates == Six candidates were nominated. They are listed below in descending order of votes.
1. Mrs Virginia Hilda Brunette Maxwell Bottomley (born 1948), was the Conservative candidate. She was a part-time psychiatric social worker, at the time of the by-election. She is married to [[Peter Bottomley]] who has also served as a Conservative MP.
Mrs Bottomley had contested the [[Isle of Wight (UK Parliament constituency)|Isle of Wight]] in the 1983 general election. Subsequent to the by-election she retained the seat, until she retired from the House of Commons and was granted a Life Peerage in 2005. She served as a member of [[John Major]]'s cabinet from 1992 until 1997.
2. The Liberal Party candidate, representing the [[SDP-Liberal Alliance]], was freelance journalist and broadcaster [[Gavin Scott|Gavin Douglas Scott]] (born 1950). Since the by-election Scott has become known as a screenwriter.
3. The Labour nominee was [[Barbara Roche|Mrs Barbara Maureen Roche]] (born 1954), a barrister. Mrs Roche has subsequently been elected to Parliament and has served as a junior minister.
4. Victor Litvin was an Independent candidate, who upset some people with his unique ballot paper label.
5. Miss Helen Mary Anscomb was an Independent candidate, who frequently contested by-elections in the 1980s.
6. Peter Reid Smith, was another Independent candidate.

The '''2010 Georgian news report hoax''' was a fake news report aired by [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] television station [[Imedi TV]] on 13 March 2010.
==The broadcast== ''Special Report'' is a weekly programme which is broadcast on [[Imedi TV]] on Saturdays at 8:30pm. On 13 March 2010, Imedi brought forward the programme to 7:59pm, the timeslot allocated to ''Chronicle''. ''Chronicle'' which runs at 8:00pm is a major source of information for Imedi TV viewers.<ref name="intentionally">{{cite news|url=http://www.geotimes.ge/index.php?m=home&newsid=20848|title=Facts Suggest Imedi Video Was Intentionally Confusing|last=Khachidze|first=Keti|date=16 March 2010|publisher=[[Georgian Times]]|accessdate=24 March 2010}}</ref>
[[File:President of Georgia Mikheil Saakashvili in Tbilisi, March 22, 2008.jpg|thumb|President [[Mikheil Saakashvili]] was reported to have been assassinated in the fake report.]] The fake news report, which heavily utilised footage from the 2008 war in South Ossetia,<ref name="opdemandapolrian" /> began by Imedi accusing the Georgian opposition of the organisation of protests in [[Tbilisi]] due to alleged fraud in the Tbilisi city elections which were scheduled for 30 May. During the protests, unknown gunmen opened fire on the protestors, killing some. As a result, the opposition pleaded for the [[international community]] to assist in ousting the "Saakashvili tyranny".<ref name="pavelexploit">{{cite news|url=http://georgiandaily.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=17799&Itemid=132|title=Moscow Exploits TV Invasion Hoax to Isolate Georgia |last=Felgenhauer|first=Pavel|authorlink=Pavel Felgenhauer|date=19 March 2010|publisher=[[Georgian Daily]]|accessdate=28 March 2010}}</ref> Following the protest in Tbilisi, an ambush in the [[South Ossetia]]n capital of [[Tskhinval]]i occurred, which killed the [[President of South Ossetia]] [[Eduard Kokoity]]. Moscow announced that it held proof of the involvement of Georgian security services in the Kokoity assassination, which Russia deemed to be a [[terrorist attack]].<ref name="pavelexploit" /> Allegedly pro-Russian opposition politicians, led by [[Nino Burdzhanadze]] and [[Zurab Nogaideli]] travelled to Tskhinval and accused Saakashvili of the killing of Kokoity.<ref name="pavelexploit" /> After the assassination, [[Russian Ground Forces|Russian Army]] troops were mobilized and put on high alert. [[Georgian Land Forces|Georgian Army]] troops were mobilized, and took defensive positions around Tbilisi with heavy artillery. A ''people's government'' with Burdzhanadze at the helm declared the government of Saakashvili "illegal".<ref name="pavelexploit" /> Other Georgian opposition politicians who were held up as collaborators with the Russians included [[Zurab Dzidziguri]], [[Kakha Kukava]], [[Koba Davitashvili]], [[Levan Gachechiladze]] and [[Giorgi Khaindrava]].<ref name="opdemandapolrian">{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100325/158304323.html|title=Georgian opposition demands apologies for fake invasion report|date=25 March 2010|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|accessdate=28 March 2010|location=[[Tbilisi]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100326222716/http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100325/158304323.html| archivedate= 26 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> [[Russian President]] [[Dmitry Medvedev]] is shown, with a Georgian voiceover, allegedly saying “Since the Saakashvili regime began open terrorism against South Ossetia, this international criminal must be stopped. I have ordered a military operation, and call on the Georgian people not to resist the troops that bring them freedom.” <ref name="pavelexploit" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.polit.ru/news/2010/03/14/9.html|script-title=ru:"Война миров" по-грузински: полный текст и видео программы о вторжении россиян|date=14 March 2010|publisher=Polit.ru|accessdate=28 March 2010|language=ru}}</ref> The broadcast then showed Russian tanks, which were based in the [[Akhalgori]] region in South Ossetia, entering the Georgian capital, and several Georgian battalions were reported to have defected and sided with the people's government.<ref name="pavelexploit" /> Saakashvili is pronounced as having possibly been assassinated, which was allegedly announced by the [[Movement for Fair Georgia]]; the political party headed by former [[Prime Minister of Georgia|Georgian Prime Minister]] and current opposition politician, [[Zurab Nogaideli]].<ref name="pavelexploit" /> However, other reports had stated that Saakashvili was alive in a hidden location and still in command. The broadcast stated that the West stood by and issued only "halfhearted protests".<ref name="pavelexploit" /> A speech said to have been given by President Saakashvili is shown, where he stated that Russia wanted to become an Empire, and instructed all eligible Georgians to join the military. Meanwhile, Russian planes are reported to have bombed targets all over Georgia, and Georgian volunteers are reported to be engaged in combat in [[Mtskheta]]. The report also included the scenario of the aircraft carrying [[Polish President]] [[Lech Kaczyński]] to Tbilisi being blown up, leading to the Polish President's death.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.regnum.ru/news/1263229.html |script-title=ru:Грузинская телекомпания Имеди "похоронила" президента Польши |date=15 March 2010 |publisher=[[Regnum News Agency]] |accessdate=12 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100413162805/http://www.regnum.ru/news/1263229.html |archivedate=13 April 2010 |deadurl=no |language=ru |df= }}</ref>
===Effects=== During the broadcast, public panic was sparked in Georgia, as many Georgians did not see the disclaimer at the beginning of the broadcast, and assumed that they were watching live events.<ref name="bogusbbc" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20100313/158186479.html|title=Georgians panic over mock TV news report of Russian invasion|date=13 March 2010|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|accessdate=28 March 2010|location=[[Tbilisi]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100317155910/http://en.rian.ru/world/20100313/158186479.html| archivedate= 17 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="mollycorso">{{cite news|url=http://www.eurasiareview.com/2010/03/32526-fake-georgia-tv-report-about.html|title=Fake Georgia TV Report About Russian Invasion Stranger Than Fiction |last=Corso|first=Molly|date=16 March 2010|publisher=Eurasia Review|accessdate=28 March 2010|location=[[Tbilisi]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100323210835/http://www.eurasiareview.com/2010/03/32526-fake-georgia-tv-report-about.html| archivedate= 23 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Thousands of telephone calls to emergency services were made, citizens hurried to withdraw cash from [[automatic teller machines]], Georgian mobile phone networks crashed, and many prepared to flee Tbilisi and villages and towns near the border with South Ossetia.<ref name="alberici" /><ref name="rferlwhitmore">{{cite news|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/Saakashvilis_Erratic_Response_To_Invasion_Hoax_Raises_Suspicions/1984530.html |title=Saakashvili's Erratic Response To Invasion Hoax Raises Suspicions |last=Whitmore |first=Brian |author2=RFE/RL Georgian Service |date=15 March 2010 |publisher=[[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] |accessdate=28 March 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100323015018/http://www.rferl.org/content/Saakashvilis_Erratic_Response_To_Invasion_Hoax_Raises_Suspicions/1984530.html |archivedate=23 March 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Some units of the [[Georgian Land Forces|Georgian Army]] took up defensive positions after hearing of the alleged invasion.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5cWMbWJRokE |title=Primetime Panic: Spoof report sparks fear and protests in Georgia |accessdate=2010-04-09| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100323032454/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5cWMbWJRokE| archivedate= 23 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> [[Interfax]] began reporting the news in Russia of the invasion of Georgia and the assassination of Saakashvili, before David Cracknell, an employee of the Georgian government, sent a two-word text message to foreign journalists with the words "Not true".<ref name="timehoax" />
Three people died while watching the hoax. Gaioz Odishelidze, a 50-year-old man from [[Aragvispiri]] in the [[Dusheti]] district, suffered a fatal heart attack whilst watching the program. According to his son, Odishelidze cried out "What the hell's going on?", before grabbing his chest and collapsing. An ambulance rushed to the scene, but paramedics were unable to revive him.<ref name="onemore" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.georgiatimes.info/en/news/32209.html|title=On [sic] more death due to Imedi program|date=17 March 2010|publisher=[[Georgian Times]]|accessdate=25 March 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://lenta.ru/news/2010/03/19/two/|script-title=ru:После просмотра сюжета "Имеди" скончались два человека|date=19 March 2010|publisher=[[Lenta.ru]]|accessdate=25 March 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100325145501/http://lenta.ru/news/2010/03/19/two/| archivedate= 25 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no|language=ru}}</ref> Vano Nasaridze, a 75-year-old resident of [[Tbilisi]] (and a refugee from [[Sukhumi]]), suffered a stroke whilst watching the broadcast. Nasaridze's family took him to hospital on 14 March, where he underwent surgery, but died several days later.<ref name="onemore">{{cite news|url=http://www.humanrights.ge/index.php?a=news&id=7633&lang=en|title=One More Person Died Because of Imedi Reportage|last=Khutsishvili|first=Tako|date=23 March 2010|publisher=Human Rights Centre|accessdate=25 March 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.ruvr.ru/2010/03/19/5445890.html|title=Another Georgian dies over Imedi’s fake invasion report|date=19 March 2010|publisher=[[Voice of Russia]]|accessdate=25 March 2010}}</ref> Nasaridze's family announced their intention to sue Imedi, insisting that the program was responsible for his death.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.am/eng/news/17065.html|title=Another man dies in Georgia after Russian invasion hoax on Imedi|date=19 March 2010|publisher=News.am|accessdate=27 March 2010}}</ref> A woman whose son was serving in the Georgian Army died of a heart attack while watching the program.<ref name="onemore"/>
==Domestic reaction== The opposition in Georgia condemned the programme,<ref name="csmonitorweir" /> which has been compared to the [[The War of the Worlds (radio)|1938 ''The War of the Worlds'' radio broadcast]],<ref name="csmonitorweir" /><ref name="paulgoble">{{cite news|url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/columns/1328/article/war-of-the-worlds-broadcast-highlights-pathologies-of-georgian-russian-relations/401965.html|title=‘War of the Worlds’ Broadcast Highlights Pathologies of Georgian-Russian Relations |last=Goble|first=Paul|authorlink=Paul Goble|date=17 March 2010|publisher=[[The Moscow Times]]|accessdate=28 March 2010|location=[[Vienna]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100429221024/http://www.themoscowtimes.com/columns/1328/article/war-of-the-worlds-broadcast-highlights-pathologies-of-georgian-russian-relations/401965.html| archivedate= 29 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="dailycaller">{{cite news|url=http://dailycaller.com/2010/03/18/georgian-war-of-the-worlds/|title=Georgian ‘War of the Worlds’|last=Bakuria|first=Tsotne|date=18 March 2010|publisher=[[The Daily Caller]]|accessdate=28 March 2010}}</ref> and accused Saakashvili of involvement.<ref name="opdemandapolrian" /><ref name="alberici">{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/03/15/2845623.htm?section=justin|title=Georgia accused of approving Russian invasion hoax|last=Alberici|first=Emma|date=15 March 2010|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=27 March 2010}}</ref>
[[Nino Burdzhanadze]], the leader of [[Democratic Movement-United Georgia]] opposition party, stated her belief that Saakashvili ordered the programme aired to increase [[anti-Russian sentiment]] and to tarnish the Georgian opposition.<ref name="alberici" /><ref name="csmonitorweir">{{cite news|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/layout/set/print/content/view/print/287492|title=Georgia opposition leader slams Russian invasion hoax in interview|last=Weir|first=Fred|date=15 March 2010|publisher=[[Christian Science Monitor]]|accessdate=25 March 2010|location=[[Moscow]]}}</ref> Burdzhanadze's party also announced that it will file a lawsuit against Imedi.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100316/158209710.html|title=Hoax report intended to blacken Saakashvili's rivals — opposition|date=16 March 2010|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|accessdate=28 March 2010|location=[[Moscow]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100317162841/http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100316/158209710.html| archivedate= 17 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100314/158191046.html|title=Georgian opposition to sue TV channel over fake invasion report|date=14 March 2010|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|accessdate=28 March 2010|location=[[Tbilisi]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100317151433/http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100314/158191046.html| archivedate= 17 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Former [[President of Georgia (country)|Georgian President]] [[Eduard Shevardnadze]] condemned the programme and said that it was intimidation by the [[Government of Georgia (country)|Georgian government]] of its own people. Shevardnadze also stated that the programme proved then [[President of Russia|Russian President]] [[Dmitry Medvedev]] correct in his decision not to hold discussions with Saakashvili.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.ruvr.ru/2010/03/18/5419273.html|title=Ex-Georgian President upholds opposition visit to Moscow |date=18 March 2010|publisher=[[Voice of Russia]]|accessdate=25 March 2010}}</ref> Catholicos [[Patriarch Ilia II of Georgia]] condemned the programme, saying it was an insult to Georgia's people and [[Georgian Armed Forces|army]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.interfax-religion.com/?act=news&div=7029|title=Georgian Patriarch slams Imedi TV provocation|date=15 March 2010|publisher=[[Interfax]]|accessdate=25 March 2010|location=[[Tbilisi]]}}</ref>
In a poll run by [[Kviris Palitra]], 63% of the 406 respondents believe that Saakashvili was involved in the preparation of the fake report, whilst 8.7% believe the President was uninvolved, with 28.3% indicating they were unsure.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.interpressnews.ge/en/index.php/permalink/16424.html |title=63.0 Percent of Respondents Consider Mikheil Saakashvili Participated in Preparation of Simulated Chronicle |date=29 March 2010 |publisher=Interpressnews.ge |accessdate=6 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004201756/http://www.interpressnews.ge/en/index.php/permalink/16424.html |archivedate=October 4, 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.georusparitet.com/official_statement/20100329/151340911.html|script-title=ru:Саакашвили был причастен к "спецрепортажу" "Имеди" ? - опрос|last=Dzhavakhia|first=Eka|date=29 March 2010|publisher=Россиа - Грузиа: Информационный Паритет|accessdate=17 May 2012|location=[[Tbilisi]]|language=ru}}</ref>
===Georgian journalist reactions=== The Imedi broadcast was condemned by many Georgian journalists who took part in protests at the Imedi TV building.<ref name="bogusbbc" /> Giorgi Udzilauri, a journalist with the [[Akhali Taoba]] newspaper noted that the programme demonstrated that [[propaganda]] has a large influence in Georgia, and went on to say that the programme was a test of public reaction towards the Georgian government's "next violence and military adventure", and that it appears the Government still holds such plans. Udzilauri also called Imedi a "propaganada trumpet" of the government, and stated his belief that those responsible should be taken to court, as creating panic is a crime against the State.<ref name="journodenounce">{{cite news|url=http://www.geotimes.ge/index.php?m=home&newsid=20949|title=Georgian Journalists Denounce Imedi Hoax Video|last=Tsivkarashvili|first=Shorena|date=22 March 2010|publisher=[[The Georgian Times]]|accessdate=28 March 2010}}</ref> Luba Eliashvili stated their belief that Imedi should be charged, however, new laws in Georgia do not provide significant penalties. Eliashvili also stated that a positive outcome of the report is that people have lost their trust in Imedi and the "Mischists" forever.<ref name="journodenounce" /> Gia Iakobashvili, the Editor-in-Chief of presa.ge, stated their belief that all journalists should protest against Imedi, and that journalists should not participate in any Imedia programming.<ref name="journodenounce" /> Giorgi Mamatsashvili, a journalist with the [[Asaval-Dasavali]] newspaper, regarded the programme as a staged show, and after hearing the alleged telephone conversation between Tsamalashvili and Arveladze, stated his belief that the programme had the intent of creating panic and to implement the Government's ideology. Mamatsashvili also said that "Imedi has become a house of prostitution. This Government’s ideology is to fight against the Patriarch and destroy the Church."<ref name="journodenounce" />
The Council of the Charter of Journalistic Ethics in Georgia had a meeting on 25 March 2010, in which they discussed journalistic ethics in the Georgian media. ''Special Report'' anchor Natia Koberidze was due to attend the meeting but later withdrew. Koberidze stated that she was ready to attend the Council meeting, but due to its public format, decided to withdraw as the meeting could be used as a mean to attack her. Eter Turadze, the Council head, stated at the meeting that it was not being held to punish anyone, although sanctions could be considered if the Council felt that journalistic ethical norms were breached. Turadze also said that the stated aim of the meeting was to call upon journalists to act according to ethical norms.<ref name="gvantsa" /> As a result of Koberidze's non-attendance at the meeting, the Council sent her 16 questions via email, which among other things asked her who was responsible for the fake news report being broadcast with visible warnings that it was only a simulation, and whether she had been put under any pressure. Koberidze replied to the questionnaire by saying that she did not violate the Charter, as warnings were given to viewers as the programme began that it was a simulation. She also stated she was not aware who was responsible for the absence of visible warnings during the programme.<ref name="gvantsa" />
===Imedi response=== [[Giorgi Arveladze]], the [[General Director]] of Imedi TV, stated that the purpose of the program was to demonstrate to Georgians the external threats that they were faced with,<ref name="intentionally" /> saying, "The really unpleasant thing about yesterday's report — and I want everyone to understand this well — is that this report is as close to reality as possible, to what may really happen, and to what Georgia's enemies keep in mind".<ref name="telegraph">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/georgia/7442366/Russia-invasion-spoof-report-spreads-panic-in-Georgia.html|title=Russia invasion spoof report spreads panic in Georgia|last=Osborn|first=Andrew|date=14 March 2010|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|accessdate=24 March 2010|location=[[Moscow]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100317132431/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/georgia/7442366/Russia-invasion-spoof-report-spreads-panic-in-Georgia.html| archivedate= 17 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Arveladze apologised for the panic which the broadcast caused in Georgia, but defended the report, and dismissed calls for him to resign. Whilst Arveladze refused to be drawn into questions on whether the broadcast breached the [[code of conduct]] for broadcasters, the [[Georgian National Communications Commission]] and the Young Lawyers' Association of Georgia said that Imedi had violated the code with its broadcast.<ref name="civilimedidefend">{{cite news|url=http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=22083|title=Imedi TV Chief Defends Fake Report|date=15 March 2010|publisher=[[Civil Georgia]]|accessdate=28 March 2010|location=[[Tbilisi]]}}</ref> The Imedi chief was also forced to defend against allegations that top officials in the Georgian government, including Saakashvili, were informed about the programme before it went to air.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100316/158208735.html|title=Imedi head denies informing officials of fake report beforehand|date=16 March 2010|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|accessdate=28 March 2010|location=[[Tbilisi]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100317162447/http://www.en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100316/158208735.html| archivedate= 17 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> After a finding by the GNMC that the broadcast violated the broadcaster's code of conduct,<ref name="frenchrian" /> the broadcaster was directed to make a public apology.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.trend.az/regions/scaucasus/georgia/1654573.html|title=Imedi television obliged with apology |last=Kirtskhalia|first=N.|date=15 March 2010|publisher=[[Trend News Agency]]|accessdate=28 March 2010|location=[[Tbilisi]]}}</ref>
===Government response===
On 14 March 2010, speaking to residents in the [[Bolnisi]] region, Saakashvili appeared to defend the broadcast,<ref name="rferlwhitmore" /><ref name="csmonitorweir" /><ref name="esslemont">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8568762.stm|title=Georgians question un-reality TV |last=Esslemont|first=Tom|date=15 March 2010|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=28 March 2010|location=[[Tbilisi]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100322231732/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8568762.stm| archivedate= 22 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> and stated "(i)t was indeed a very unpleasant program, but the most unpleasant thing is that it is extremely close to what can happen and to what Georgia's enemy has conceived".<ref name="csmonitorweir" /> The only part of the fake report that Saakashvili specifically objected to was the part which said that some of the [[Army of Georgia|Georgian Army]] had joined forces with the Russians, as it is according to Saakashvili an insult to those who are fighting for Georgia. However, during the [[Mukhrovani Mutiny]] Saakashvili called the same soldiers traitors and accused them of working for Russia. Military expert Giorgi Melitauri accused those behind the Mukhrovani Mutiny; those who carry out Saakashvili's propaganda orders; of being behind the writing of the programme.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.geotimes.ge/index.php?m=home&newsid=20939|title=Giorgi Melitauri: The programme was written by the same people who staged the Mukhrovani Mutiny|last=Bzhalava|first=Dali|author2=Melitauri, Giorgi|date=22 March 2010|publisher=[[The Georgian Times]]|accessdate=28 March 2010}}</ref> On 15 March 2010, a written statement appeared on the Georgian President's website, in which, aside from accusing Russia of having aggressive plans against Georgia, he called for higher journalistic ethical standards to prevent such incidents in the future.<ref name="rferlwhitmore" />
[[Prime Minister of Georgia|Georgian Prime Minister]] [[Nika Gilauri]] speaking in [[Brussels]] rejected the notion that the government exercised any control over Imedi, citing the station's private ownership;<ref name="frustration" /> despite this, the station is widely perceived as being under the control of the government in Tbilisi.<ref name="burnishingspiegel">{{cite news|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,684192,00.html |title=Burnishing a Tarnished Image: Georgia Mounts American PR Campaign |last=Bidder |first=Benjamin |date=17 March 2010 |publisher=[[Der Spiegel]] |accessdate=28 March 2010 |location=[[Moscow]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100322235210/http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0%2C1518%2C684192%2C00.html |archivedate=22 March 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
===Taped telephone recordings=== On 15 March 2010, an audio recording alleged to be a telephone conversation between Arveladze and his deputy Eka Tsamalashvili was released by ''Forum.ge''; because of Arveladze's close ties to Saakashvili this raised suspicions that the Saakashvili had been involved in the broadcast.<ref name="rferlwhitmore" /><ref name="messengermzia" /> In the recording, a woman, allegedly Tsamalashvili, says that airing the report as if it were genuine news would be a violation of the Georgian Law on Broadcasting, and stated that a notification should be carried on screen telling viewers of the fake report that it was a simulation. A man, allegedly Arveladze, responds to the suggestion by saying that he had spoken to "Misha" — a nickname for Saakashvili — the day previous, and after being asked by Saakashvili whether the programme would be put to air as a regular Chronicle programme, he told him that it would. The man continued to say that he told Saakashvili that viewers would be told at the beginning of the broadcast that the programme was a simulation, but Saakashvili said not to do so, ostensibly because it would affect the effect of the programme.<ref name="messengermzia">{{cite news|url=http://www.messenger.com.ge/issues/2065_march_17_2010/2065_mzia.html|title=Taped phone conversation fuels discussions over Imedi TV hoax report|last=Kupunia |first=Mzia|date=17 March 2010|publisher=[[The Messenger (Georgia)]]|accessdate=28 March 2010}}</ref> The man goes on to say that the general plot outline had been provided to [[Ghia Nodia]] and [[Zurab Davitashvili]], both former members of Saakashvili's government. After being asked about the plot outline, both Nodia and Davitashvili confirmed that they had received it from the television network prior to the broadcast.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=22088|title=Phone Tape Adds New Twist to Fake TV Report|date=16 March 2010|publisher=[[Civil Georgia]]|accessdate=28 March 2010|location=[[Tbilisi]]}}</ref>
Arveladze denied the conversation took place and accused the Russian special services of fabricating the tape by stitching together phrases from different conversations to produce the recording. Tsamalashvili called the recording "absurd and a lie", and dismissed suggestions that she had received directions from government officials whilst working at Imedi. She also suggested involvement of Russian special services in the alleged fabrication.<ref name="messengermzia" /> Independent analyst Irakli Sesiashvili stated that the recording was "very close" to authentic, and stated his belief that the voices on the recording matched the alleged speakers manner of speaking. Sesiashvili also stated that it is impossible to "maintain natural intonation and idiolect in a fabricated tape".<ref name="messengermzia" />
On 16 March 2010, an audio recording of an alleged telephone conversation between Saakashvili and the [[Minister of Culture (Georgia)|Georgian Minister of Culture]] [[Nika Rurua]] was anonymously posted online, and was partially aired by [[Rustavi 2]] in its 6pm [[news bulletin]]. In the recording, a man, allegedly Rurua calling from [[Paris]], asks whether the panic caused by the program had "calmed down". In response, another man, allegedly Saakashvili, says that the panic only lasted five minutes, and that Imedi should have placed a caption below the screen to advise viewers it was a simulation. The second man then says that the programme had predicted quite accurately the "Russian scenario", and that he had spoken to Arveladze and told this to him.<ref name="saakrecordcivil">{{cite news|url=http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=22093|title=More Fake TV Report-Related Phone Recording|date=16 March 2010|publisher=[[Civil Georgia]]|accessdate=27 March 2010|location=[[Tbilisi]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/recording-alleges-georgian-president-blame-fake-invasion-panic/story?id=10123722&page=1|title=Recording Alleges Georgian President to Blame for Fake Invasion Panic|last=Marquardt|first=Alexander|date=17 March 2010|publisher=[[ABC News]]|accessdate=28 March 2010|location=[[Moscow]]}}</ref> Rurua accused the [[Federal Security Service|Russian Federal Security Service]] of fabricating the recording.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=22104|title=Authorities Rule Out Probe into Fake TV Report-Related Phone Recordings|date=19 March 2010|publisher=[[Civil Georgia]]|accessdate=28 March 2010|location=[[Tbilisi]]}}</ref>
Irakli Sesiashvili suggested that [[Minister of the Interior (Georgia)|Georgian Interior Minister]] [[Vano Merabishvili]], or [[Ministry of the Interior (Georgia)|his ministry]], which is believed to engage in illegal phone-tapping, was behind the leaking of the telephone recordings to the internet, ostensibly in an attempt to discredit Saakashvili.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/Georgian_Minister_Rules_Out_Probe_Into_Incriminating_Tapes/1989195.html|title=Georgian Minister Rules Out Probe Into Incriminating Tapes|date=20 March 2010|publisher=[[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]]|accessdate=28 March 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100406224832/http://www.rferl.org/content/Georgian_Minister_Rules_Out_Probe_Into_Incriminating_Tapes/1989195.html| archivedate= 6 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> [[Irakli Alasania]], the leader of [[Alliance for Georgia]], pressed authorities to carry out expert analysis of the recordings, and also said that foreign experts should participate in verifying whether the recordings are authentic. [[Giorgi Targamadze]], the leader of the [[Christian-Democratic Movement]], called for an ad-hoc parliamentary commission to investigate the case, but his proposal was knocked back by lawmakers of the ruling party, who dismissed it as "not serious".<ref name="saakrecordcivil" />
==International reaction== Andrei Nesterenko, the spokesman for the [[Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] said the Imedi program was irresponsible and immoral, and that Russia understood the anger in Georgia as a result of the airing. He also accused the government in Georgia of "political paranoia".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mid.ru/brp_4.nsf/e78a48070f128a7b43256999005bcbb3/454885fac2ef9b59c32576e7005a574c?OpenDocument|title=Russian MFA Spokesman Andrei Nesterenko Response to Media Query Regarding the Recent Georgian Imedi TV Broadcast|date=15 March 2010|publisher=[[Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs]]|accessdate=24 March 2010}}</ref><ref name="russiacondemnsbbc">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8568836.stm|title=Russia condemns Georgian TV's 'immoral' invasion hoax |date=15 March 2010|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=27 March 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100324004942/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8568836.stm| archivedate= 24 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Nesterenko also stated that Saakashvili's comments on the programme amounted to his approval of its contents.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=22085|title=Russian MFA Slams Imedi TV’s Fake Report|date=15 March 2010|publisher=[[Civil Georgia]]|accessdate=27 March 2010|location=[[Tbilisi]]}}</ref> [[Dmitry Rogozin]], the [[Permanent Representative of Russia to NATO]], in an interview with [[RT (TV network)|Russia Today]] said that the programme was a grandiose provocation, and was the continuation of an [[information warfare|information war]] that Saakashvili continued to wage against Russia.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100315/158194666.html|title=Georgian TV fake invasion report "part of information war against Russia"|date=15 March 2010|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|accessdate=25 March 2010|location=[[Moscow]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100317155803/http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100315/158194666.html| archivedate= 17 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> [[Sergey Alexandrovich Markov|Sergey Markov]], a member of the Russian [[State Duma]], opined that the programme was aimed at the opposition forces in Georgia, rather than Russia. Markov also stated that hatred towards Russia was part of Saakashvili's political agenda, and that it was a priority that those who cross him by seeking contacts with Russia be discredited,<ref name="csmonitorhancock">{{cite news|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/terrorism-security/2010/0315/Russian-invasion-hoax-has-Georgia-opposition-in-uproar|title=Russian invasion hoax has Georgia opposition in uproar|last=Hancock|first=Ben|date=15 March 2010|publisher=[[Christian Science Monitor]]|accessdate=25 March 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100322191806/http://www.csmonitor.com/World/terrorism-security/2010/0315/Russian-invasion-hoax-has-Georgia-opposition-in-uproar| archivedate= 22 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> whilst according to [[BBC News]], some also saw the report as a thinly veiled swipe at Georgian opposition figures who met [[Prime Minister of Russia|Russian Prime Minister]] [[Vladimir Putin]] in an attempt to mend [[Georgia–Russia relations]].<ref name="bogusbbc">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8566571.stm|title=Bogus TV report of Russian invasion panics Georgia |date=14 March 2010|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=25 March 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100317002707/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8566571.stm| archivedate= 17 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> [[Nino Burdzhanadze]] met with Putin in [[Moscow]] the week before the report, and was accused of treason by parliamentary allies of Saakashvili.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.beta.rian.ru/russia/20100304/158095118.html|title=Putin views reopening of Russia-Georgia border as positive sign|date=4 March 2010|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|accessdate=25 March 2010|location=[[Moscow]]}}</ref> Russian media outlets also announced intent to sue Imedi for [[copyright infringement]], after the Georgian station used footage without permission from the Russian copyright holders.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lifenews.ru/news/16847|script-title=ru:Российские СМИ подают в суд на "Имеди"|date=16 March 2010|publisher=[[LifeNews|Life.ru]]|accessdate=28 March 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100322190507/http://www.lifenews.ru/news/16847| archivedate= 22 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no|language=ru}}</ref>
In calling the report irresponsible, [[Éric Fournier]], the [[Ambassador of France to Georgia|French ambassador to Georgia]], condemned the use of his image in the fake report. Imedi used archive footage of Fournier talking to journalists, and portrayed Fournier as telling viewers of results of meetings with the Georgian Foreign Minister, where they were briefed on Russia's military operations. Archive footage of the [[United Kingdom|British]] and [[Czech Republic|Czech]] ambassadors were also used in the same segment.<ref name="frenchrian">{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20100316/158214073.html|title=French ambassador blasts Imedi hoax report on Russian invasion|date=16 March 2010|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|accessdate=28 March 2010|location=[[Tbilisi]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100322194539/http://en.rian.ru/world/20100316/158214073.html| archivedate= 22 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=22094|title=French Ambassador on Fake TV Report|date=16 March 2010|publisher=[[Civil Georgia]]|accessdate=25 March 2010|location=[[Tbilisi]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.ruvr.ru/2010/03/16/5342677.html|title=French ambassador to Georgia perplexed at Imedi hoax|date=16 March 2010|publisher=[[Voice of Russia]]|accessdate=28 March 2010}}</ref> [[Denis Keefe]], the [[Ambassador of the United Kingdom to Georgia|British ambassador in Tbilisi]], stated the use of archive footage of himself was a discourtesy to him as Ambassador, and that the program did a disservice to Georgia's reputation as having a responsible and independent media. Keefe also complained that the program suggested that Saakashvili had held discussions with the [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|British Prime Minister]] [[Gordon Brown]] about the "non-existent events described", and stated that neither he, nor the [[Government of the United Kingdom|British government]] had any involvement in or previous knowledge of, what he called, Imedi's irresponsible programme.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8570312.stm|title=UK ambassador's protest at Georgia TV hoax|date=16 March 2010|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=25 March 2010}}</ref> The Ambassador also demanded that Imedi apologise and make it clear that it used his image without his consent or permission.<ref name="halpin" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.news.sky.com/eurovision/Post:4fb81a11-bd3c-4ed9-b556-acfbf0808c9b|title=Saakashvili and his Theatre of Clowns|last=Rossi|first=Alex|date=17 March 2010|publisher=[[Sky News]]|accessdate=28 March 2010}}</ref> [[United States Ambassador to Georgia]] [[John R. Bass|John Bass]] called the broadcast irresponsible and perturbing, and said it was not helpful in improving the security situation in the region.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.geotimes.ge/index.php?m=home&newsid=20835|title=John Bass Termed Bogus ‘Chronicle’ on Imedi TV as Perturbing|date=15 March 2010|publisher=[[The Georgian Times]]|accessdate=28 March 2010}}</ref>
The [[European Union]] Monitoring Mission in Georgia stated that the airing of the program was irresponsible and had the potential to further destabilise the region, with the possibility of a resumption of military actions between Russian and Georgian troops. The Mission kept in constant contact with the [[Russian Border Guards]] and the [[Government of South Ossetia]] during the broadcast via the Incident Prevention and Response Mechanism hotline to ensure that alert levels remained at the status quo.<ref name="halpin">{{cite news|url=http://civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=22092&search=imedi%20tv%20report|title=EU Monitors Warn Against Fake TV Report|date=16 March 2010|publisher=[[Civil.ge]]|accessdate=17 March 2012|location=[[Moscow]]}}</ref><ref name="eumm">{{cite news|url=http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=22092|title=EU Monitors Warn Against Fake TV Report|date=16 March 2010|publisher=[[Civil Georgia]]|accessdate=24 March 2010|location=[[Tbilisi]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.geotimes.ge/index.php?m=home&newsid=20862|title=EUMM expresses concern about Imedi scandal|date=16 March 2010|publisher=''[[The Georgian Times]]''/[[Rustavi 2]]|accessdate=28 March 2010}}</ref> [[European Commission President]] [[Jose Manuel Barroso]], after a meeting with [[Prime Minister of Georgia|Georgian Prime Minister]] [[Nika Gilauri]] in [[Brussels]], expressed his concern over the hoax news report and said the [[European Union]] is "hopeful that intensive work will continue to consolidate democratic institutions, create an inclusive political culture, and ensure full media freedom."<ref name="frustration">{{cite news|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/In_EU_Frustration_With_Georgia_Now_Evident/1987346.html|title=In EU, Frustration With Georgia Now Evident|last=Lobjakas|first=Ahto|date=18 March 2010|publisher=[[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]]|accessdate=27 March 2010|location=[[Brussels]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100324175232/http://www.rferl.org/content/In_EU_Frustration_With_Georgia_Now_Evident/1987346.html| archivedate= 24 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=22099&search=imedi|title=EU's Barroso 'Concerned' over Imedi TV Fake Report|date=17 March 2010|publisher=[[Civil Georgia]]|accessdate=28 March 2010|location=[[Tbilisi]]}}</ref> Barroso also called on the Georgian government to refrain from activities which could increase local and regional tensions.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE62G3XB20100317|title=EU urges Georgia not to aggravate Russia tensions|last=Brunnstrom|first=David|author2=Barkin, Noah|date=17 March 2010|publisher=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=28 March 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100323074156/https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE62G3XB20100317| archivedate= 23 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
[[NATO]] spokesman [[James Appathurai]] in a briefing in Brussels on 24 March 2010 called the false news report "unwise" and "useless".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://rt.com/Top_News/2010-03-24/nato-blasts-false-georgian.html|title=NATO blasts false Georgian TV report|date=24 March 2010|publisher=[[RT (TV network)|Russia Today]]|accessdate=28 March 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100328210429/http://rt.com/Top_News/2010-03-24/nato-blasts-false-georgian.html| archivedate= 28 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Appathurai also stated that the incident had not been viewed positively within NATO,<ref name="gvantsa">{{cite news|url=http://www.messenger.com.ge/issues/2072_march_26_2010/2072_gvanca.html|title=Now NATO and US attack Imedi hoax |last=Gabekhadze|first=Gvantsa|date=26 March 2010|publisher=[[The Messenger (Georgia)]]|accessdate=28 March 2010}}</ref> but would not affect [[Georgia–NATO relations|Georgia's aspirations to enter the alliance]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=22118|title=NATO: Fake TV Report 'Unwise'|date=25 March 2010|publisher=[[Civil Georgia]]|accessdate=28 March 2010|location=[[Tbilisi]]}}</ref>
[[President of Abkhazia|Abkhaz President]] [[Sergei Bagapsh]] called the programme "tremendous idiocy" and said that no attention should be paid to the contents of the program.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/russia/20100315/158202554.html|title=Moscow irked by bogus TV report of Russian invasion|date=15 March 2010|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|accessdate=25 March 2010|location=[[Moscow]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100322190507/http://en.rian.ru/russia/20100315/158202554.html| archivedate= 22 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
On 16 March 2010, [[Time (magazine)|''TIME'']] placed the fake report at number one of the ''"Top 10 Shocking Hoaxes"'', ahead of the [[Ashley Todd mugging hoax]], [[balloon boy hoax]], [[Ochoco Dam|the KSJJ Ochoco Dam hoax]], [[Sidd Finch|Sidd Finch hoax]], [[The War of the Worlds (radio)|1938 The War of the Worlds radio hoax]], [[Anna Anderson]], [[Hitler Diaries|Hitler Diaries hoax]], [[Piltdown Man]] and the [[Great Stock Exchange Fraud of 1814]].<ref name="timehoax">{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1931133_1931132_1972067,00.html |title=Georgia On Everyone's Mind |last=Levy |first=Glen |date=16 March 2010 |publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=25 March 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100322193603/http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0%2C28804%2C1931133_1931132_1972067%2C00.html |archivedate=22 March 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/completelist/0,29569,1931133,00.html |title=Top 10 Shocking Hoaxes |last=Levy |first=Glen |date=16 March 2010 |publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=25 March 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100323165943/http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/completelist/0%2C29569%2C1931133%2C00.html |archivedate=23 March 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.geotimes.ge/index.php?m=home&newsid=20894|title=‘Simulated Chronicle’ Leading List of Top 10 Shocking and Outrageous Hoaxes|date=18 March 2010|publisher=[[The Georgian Times]]|accessdate=25 March 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100812182458/http://geotimes.ge/index.php?m=home&newsid=20894|archive-date=2010-08-12|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
[[Valeria Novodvorskaya]] alleged that the inclusion of the scenario of the blowing up of [[Lech Kaczyński|Lech Kaczyński's]] aircraft is evidence of complicity of the [[Government of Russia|Russian State]] in the death of the [[Polish President]] in a [[2010 Polish Air Force Tu-154 crash|plane crash on 10 April 2010]] in [[Smolensk Oblast]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://grani.ru/Events/Disaster/m.176940.html|script-title=ru:Жестокая посадка|last=Novodvorskaya|first=Valeria|author-link=Valeria Novodvorskaya|date=11 April 2010|publisher=Grani.ru|accessdate=12 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100412140828/http://www.grani.ru/Events/Disaster/m.176940.html| archivedate= 12 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no|language=ru}}</ref>

page.title: 27th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Unreferenced|date=May 2012}} [[File:RIAN archive 852682 XXVII Congress of the CPSU.jpg|thumb|27th Congress]] [[File:RIAN archive 770913 The final speech of the General Secretary of the CPSU Central Committee M. Gorbachev.jpg|thumbnail|Gorbachev's ending speech to the 27th Congress]] The '''27th Congress of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]]''' was held from 25 February to 6 March 1986 in [[Moscow]]. This was the first congress presided over by [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] as [[General Secretary]] of the [[Central Committee of the CPSU]]. In accordance with the pattern set 20 years earlier by [[Leonid Brezhnev]], the congress occurred five years after the previous [[26th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|CPSU Congress]]. Much had changed in those five years. Key figures of Soviet politics, [[Mikhail Suslov]], Leonid Brezhnev, [[Yuri Andropov]], [[Dmitriy Ustinov]], and [[Konstantin Chernenko]] had died, and Mikhail Gorbachev had become General Secretary of the Party. For this reason the congress was widely anticipated, both at home and abroad, as an indicator of Gorbachev's new policies and directions. The congress was attended by 4993 delegates. It elected the [[27th Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|27th Central Committee]].
The agenda of the congress: * CC CPSU Report and the Party objectives (Given by Mikhail Gorbachev) * New Party Statute release * Political report of CC CPSU * CPSU Central Revisional Commission report * Report ''About the economic and social development of the USSR on 1986-1990 and in 2000 perspective'' * Elections of the central Party organs
This Congress became the penultimate in the [[history of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union]].

Fleisher (associate producer) | editor = Corky Ehlers | location = [[Houston]] | cinematography = Mike Fash | runtime = 100 minutes | company = [[Alan Landsburg Productions]] | distributor = [[NBC]] | budget = | network = NBC | first_aired = October 10, 1983 | last_aired = | preceded_by = | followed_by = ''Adam: His Song Continues'' (1986) | website = }} '''''Adam''''' is a 1983 American [[television film|made-for-television film]] starring [[Daniel J. Travanti]] and [[JoBeth Williams]]. It aired on October 10, 1983, on [[NBC]]. On its original air date, it was seen by an audience of 38 million people.{{Citation | last = Divoky | first = Diane | title = Missing Tot Estimates Exaggerated | newspaper = [[Lodi News-Sentinel]] | pages = 2 | date = 18 February 1986 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=dXBh7-90p_YC&dat=19860218&b_mode=2 | accessdate = }} It was rebroadcast on April 30, 1984, and again on April 29, 1985. At the end of each broadcast of the film, a series of missing children's photographs and descriptions were displayed on the screen for viewers, and a number was given to call if a viewer had information about them. The 1985 photograph series was introduced by President [[Ronald Reagan]] in a pre-recorded message, "...maybe your eyes can help bring them home."{{Citation | title = 'Adam' Again Draws Callers | newspaper = [[Milwaukee Journal]] | pages = Life/Style 2 | date = 30 April 1985 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=IGoaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TCoEAAAAIBAJ&dq=adam%20walsh%20movie&pg=3542%2C10229378 | accessdate = }} A [[sequel]], ''Adam: His Song Continues'' followed on September 29, 1986, also starring Travanti and Williams. The first part of the film portrays the story of the kidnapping and [[murder of Adam Walsh]] on July 27, 1981, along with the effects of this event on the marriage of [[John Walsh (television host)|John]] and Revé Walsh. The second part of the movie focuses on the Walsh's attempts to pass national child protection laws in the wake of Adam's murder, and the formation of awareness groups surrounding child disappearances. The film was written by [[Allan Leicht]] and directed by [[Michael Tuchner]]. ==Production== Filming of the movie was conducted in and around [[Houston, Texas]]. The scenes portrayed at the Hollywood Mall of [[Hollywood, Florida]], were filmed at the now-defunct [[Westwood Mall (Houston, Texas)|Westwood Mall]] in Houston, and at the [[Sears]] which was one of its former anchor stores.{{dead link|date=November 2012}}{{Citation | title = Filming Begins on Television Movie 'Adam' | newspaper = [[St. Petersburg Times]] | pages = 26, TV Dial | date = 19 June 1983 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0R8MAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-10DAAAAIBAJ&pg=4918%2C4180091 | accessdate = 5 June 2010}}{{dead link|date=November 2012}}{{Citation | title = Filming Starts on TV Movie About Abduction-Murder Of Adam Walsh | newspaper = [[Sarasota Herald-Tribune]] | pages = Section D, State | date = 8 June 1983 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=TB0uAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cGgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2261%2C6261883 | accessdate = 30 April 2014}} The Sears store where some scenes were filmed is still standing.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} The three broadcasts of ''Adam'' were followed by pictures and descriptions of missing children as of each of the respective broadcasts. A hotline was also active, to take calls regarding the children. This was ultimately credited with finding 13 of 55 children from the 1983 broadcast, including future rapper [[Bizzy Bone]], and 19 of 51 children shown in the 1984 broadcast. As of two days after the 1985 showing, 3,522 calls had been made to the hotline, and 5 of 54 featured missing children had already been found.{{Citation | title = 3 Children Found After Showing of 'Adam' | newspaper = [[Pittsburgh Press]] | pages = A11 | date = 1 May 1985 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=TuIhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=U2IEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7130%2C53614 | accessdate = 6 June 2010}}{{Citation | title = Girl Found In North Texas After Tip To National Center | newspaper = [[The Victoria Advocate]] | page = 7F | date = 2 May 1985 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=GSoPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=VYUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6804%2C736254 | accessdate = 30 April 2014}} ==Cast== * [[Daniel J. Travanti]] as [[John Walsh (television host)|John Walsh]] * [[JoBeth Williams]] as Revé Walsh * [[Martha Scott]] as Gram Jean Walsh * [[Richard Masur]] as Jay Howell * [[Paul Regina]] as Joe Walsh * [[Mason Adams]] as Ray Mellette * [[Tony Frank (actor)|Tony Frank]] as Lt. Richard Hynds * [[John M. Jackson]] as Det. Jim Gibbons * Alex Harvey as Det. Jack Hoffman ==Awards== [[36th Primetime Emmy Awards|1984 Primetime Emmy Award]] nominations: * Outstanding Drama/Comedy Special ([[Alan Landsburg]], [[imdbname:0055920|Joan Barnett]], executive producers; [[Linda Otto]], producer) * Outstanding Lead Actor in a Limited Series or a Special ([[Daniel J. Travanti]]) * Outstanding Lead Actress in a Limited Series or a Special ([[JoBeth Williams]]) * Outstanding Writing in a Limited Series or a Special ([[imdbname:0500076|Allan Leicht]]) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=0085136|title=Adam}} * {{Amg movie|790|Adam}} {{Michael Tuchner}} [[Category:Films directed by Michael Tuchner]] [[Category:1983 television films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Films set in Florida]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:1980s drama films]] [[Category:Films shot in Houston]] [[Category:NBC network original films]] [[Category:Crime films based on actual events]] [[Category:Films about abduction]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox newspaper | name = Al Raya
الراية | logo = | image = | caption = | type = Daily newspaper | format = | owners = | founder = | publisher = Gulf company for printing and publishing | editor = Sadiq Mohammad Al Amari | chiefeditor = Saleh Al Kawari | assoceditor = | maneditor = | newseditor = | managingeditordesign = | campuseditor = | campuschief = | opeditor = | sportseditor = | photoeditor = | staff = | foundation = {{Start date and age|1979|12|10|df=yes}} | political = pro-government | language = [[Arabic language|Arabic]] | ceased publication = | headquarters = [[Doha]] | circulation = 18,000 (2008) | sister newspapers =''[[Gulf Times]]'' | ISSN = | oclc = | website = [http://www.raya.com/ ''Al Raya''] }} '''''Al Raya''''' (in [[Arabic language|Arabic]] الراية also known as ''Arrayah''; ''The Banner'' in English){{cite book|title=Mass Media in the Middle East: A Comprehensive Handbook|year=1994|publisher=''Greenwood Press''|location=Westport, CT|url=https://www.questia.com/read/23321662/mass-media-in-the-middle-east-a-comprehensive-handbook|author=Mohamed M. Arafa|editor=Yahya R. Kamalipour; Hamid Mowlana|accessdate=19 September 2013|chapter=Qatar}}{{Subscription required|via=Questia}} is an [[Arabic language|Arabic]] daily newspaper published in [[Doha]], [[Qatar]]. It is semi-official newspaper of the country and is one of the five leading Qatari dailies.{{cite web|title=Media sustainability index 2008 |url=http://www.irex.org/system/files/MSIMENA08_Qatar.pdf |work=IREX |accessdate=19 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121224211744/http://www.irex.org/system/files/MSIMENA08_Qatar.pdf |archivedate=24 December 2012 }} As for Arabic dailies published in the country ''Al Raya'' is among the three major newspapers along with ''[[Al Sharq]]'' and ''[[Al-Watan (Qatar)|Al Watan]]''.{{cite book|author1=Barrie Gunter|author2=Roger Dickinson|title=News Media in the Arab World: A Study of 10 Arab and Muslim Countries|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=89pMZd0JhDsC&pg=PA28|accessdate=27 September 2013|date=6 June 2013|publisher=A&C Black|isbn=978-1-4411-0239-3|page=28}} ==History and profile== ''Al Raya'' was launched by Gulf company for printing and publishing as a [[weekly newspaper]] on 10 December 1979.{{cite news|title=About us|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/static/aboutus|accessdate=19 September 2013|newspaper=Gulf Times}}{{cite web|title=Information and Media|url=http://www.qatarembassy.net/page/information-and-media#8|publisher=Embassy of Qatar|accessdate=11 September 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140716121901/http://www.qatarembassy.net/page/information-and-media#8|archive-date=16 July 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} The company which was founded by Ali bin Jaber Al Thani also owns ''[[Gulf Times]]'', an [[English language]] daily.{{cite web|title=Al Raya newspaper|url=http://www.pressfair.com/publication/index.php?id=154|work=Press Fair|accessdate=19 September 2013|date=17 September 2010}} Based in Doha,{{cite web|title=Al Raya and Gulf Times Newspaper|url=http://qa.wowcity.com/doha/gpid/114429688224160479258/al-raya-gulf-times-newspaper.htm|work=Wow City|accessdate=19 September 2013}} ''Al Raya'' is the second Arabic newspaper published in Qatar.{{cite book|author=William A. Rugh|title=Arab Mass Media: Newspapers, Radio, and Television in Arab Politics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UGfbluSa4N8C&pg=PA60|accessdate=19 September 2013|year=2004|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-275-98212-6|page=60}} On 27 January 1980 ''Al Raya'' was relaunched as a daily newspaper. In 1996 a corpus was created which included 187 articles published in ''Al Raya''.{{cite book|author=Blaise Cronin|title=Annual Review of Information Science and Technology 2007|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=km5ENgwjp0sC&pg=PA511|accessdate=4 October 2014|date=1 October 2006|publisher=Information Today, Inc.|isbn=978-1-57387-276-8|page=511}} On 27 April 2012 the paper launched the mapping mangroves project.{{cite web|title=Al Raya: Project Mapping Mangroves |url=http://www.qfi.org/news/199/Al-Raya:-Project-Mapping-Mangroves |work=Qatar Foundation International |accessdate=19 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921054908/http://www.qfi.org/news/199/Al-Raya%3A-Project-Mapping-Mangroves |archivedate=21 September 2013 }} In the early 1990s ''Al Raya'' had a circulation of 10,000 copies and was distributed in [[Saudi Arabia]] and [[Egypt]] in addition to its native Qatar. Until 1995 when the other Arabic daily, ''[[Al-Watan (Qatar)|Al Watan]]'', was launched the paper enjoyed higher levels of circulation, but then lost its one-third of circulation. In 2000 ''Al Raya'' was the second best selling newspaper in Qatar with a circulation of 18,000 copies.{{cite web|title=World Press Trends|url=http://www.wan-press.org/ecrire/upload/wpt2004.pdf|work=World Association of Newspapers|accessdate=8 February 2015|location=Paris|date=2004}} The estimated circulation of the paper in 2003 was 8,000 copies. ''Al Raya'''s circulation increased to 18,000 copies in 2008. The online version of the paper was the 47th most visited website for 2010 in the [[MENA region]].{{cite news|title=Forbes Releases Top 50 MENA Online Newspapers; Lebanon Fails to Make Top 10|url=http://www.jadaoun.com/2803/forbes-releases-top-50-mena-online-newspapers-lebanon-fails-to-make-top-10/|accessdate=11 September 2014|work=Jad Aoun|date=28 October 2010}} ==Political stance and content== Although ''Al Raya'' is privately owned it is the semi-official newspaper of Qatar.{{cite web|title=Qatar |url=http://www.arabpressnetwork.org/newspaysv2.php?id=126 |work=The Arab Press Network |accessdate=19 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921053932/http://www.arabpressnetwork.org/newspaysv2.php?id=126 |archivedate=21 September 2013 }}{{cite news|title=Qatar profile|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-14702519|accessdate=19 September 2013|work=BBC|date=26 July 2013}} Therefore, it has a pro-government stance.{{cite web|title=Qatar newspapers|url=http://www.worldpress.org/newspapers/MIDEAST/Qatar.cfm|work=World Press|accessdate=19 September 2013}} The major rival of the daily is another Arabic Qatari newspaper ''[[Al Sharq]]'' which has opposite political stance. ''Al Raya'' mostly provides news about the receptions and activities of the ruling family, [[Al Thani]], as well as about official events. In addition, the daily has large supplements on sports and business as well as a special supplement called ''He and She''. The paper offered a weekly page on the [[environmental issues]] from 1999 to 2005.{{cite web|author=Najib Saab |title=The Environment in Arab Media |url=http://www.afedonline.org/afedreport/english/book14.pdf |work=Arab Forum for Environment and Development |accessdate=7 October 2014 |format=Report |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141010170621/http://www.afedonline.org/afedreport/english/book14.pdf |archivedate=10 October 2014 }} Following the [[2013 Egyptian coup d'état|2013 coup]] in Egypt, ''Al Raya'' concentrated on the ongoing demonstrations of supporters of [[Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt|the Muslim Brotherhood]] and ousted President [[Mohamed Morsi]].{{cite journal|title=Of Egypt and Arabs|journal=Al Ahram Weekly|date=16 June 2013|volume=3383|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/News/3383/22/Of-Egypt-and-Arabs.aspx|accessdate=19 September 2013}} In August 2013, an editorial of the paper argued that possible US-led intervention against Syria would not be celebrated, but the [[Bashar Assad|Assad regime]] was "useless" and caused no other option than such intervention.{{cite news|title=Middle East press apprehensive over Syria|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-23878821|accessdate=19 September 2013|work=BBC|date=29 August 2013}} ==Staff== Yousef Kassim Darwish is the first [[editor-in-chief]] of the daily and its sister newspaper, ''Gulf Times''. In the initial period many leading Arab journalists wrote for the daily. As of 2012 Saleh Al Kawari was the editor-in-chief and Sadiq Mohammad Al Amari was the editor of the daily.{{cite news|title=Qatar mourns victims of shopping mall blaze|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2012/05/201252981826808662.html|accessdate=19 September 2013|work=Al Jazeera|date=3 June 2012}}{{cite news|title=Qatar denies Iran, Syria retaliation in mall fire that killed Western nationals |url=http://www.worldtribune.com/2012/06/06/qatar-denies-iran-syria-retaliation-in-mall-fire-that-killed-western-nationals/ |accessdate=19 September 2013 |work=World Tribune |date=6 June 2012 |location=Abu Dhabi |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921055422/http://www.worldtribune.com/2012/06/06/qatar-denies-iran-syria-retaliation-in-mall-fire-that-killed-western-nationals/ |archivedate=21 September 2013 }} Saleh bin Afssan Al Kuwari is the current editor-in-chief of the daily.{{cite news|author=Bassam Ramada|title=Qatar under pressure over support for Brotherhood|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/politics/2014/04/qatar-gcc-demand-stop-support-brotherhood.html#|accessdate=4 October 2014|work=Al Masry Al Youm via Al Monitor|date=23 April 2014}} ==See also== * [[List of newspapers in Qatar]] ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} ==External links== *[http://www.raya.com/ Official website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Raya, Al}} [[Category:1979 establishments in Qatar]] [[Category:Publications established in 1979]] [[Category:Newspapers published in Qatar]] [[Category:Arabic-language newspapers]] [[Category:Weekly newspapers]] [[Category:Media in Doha]]
