These were overwhelmingly carried out by unknown actors including insurgents, sectarian militias and criminals.[http://www.nejm.org/doi/pdf/10.1056/NEJMp0807240 The Weapons That Kill Civilians — Deaths of Children and Noncombatants in Iraq, 2003–2008] by Madelyn Hsiao-Rei Hicks, M.D., M.R.C.Psych., Hamit Dardagan, Gabriela Guerrero Serdán, M.A., Peter M. Bagnall, M.Res., John A. Sloboda, PhD, F.B.A., and Michael Spagat, PhD, The New England Journal of Medicine. * Attacks on diplomats and diplomatic facilities including; the bombing of the UN headquarters in Baghdad in August 2003 killing the top UN representative in Iraq and 21 other UN staff members;{{cite news|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/extra/features/jan-june06/iraq_6-12.html |title=Who are the Iraq Insurgents? |work=NewsHour with Jim Lehrer |publisher=PBS |date=12 June 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060615080821/https://www.pbs.org/newshour/extra/features/jan-june06/iraq_6-12.html |archivedate=15 June 2006 }} beheading several diplomats: two Algerian diplomatic envoys Ali Belaroussi and Azzedine Belkadi,{{cite news|url=https://freeinternetpress.com/story.php?sid=4107 |title=Kidnappers Kill Algerian Diplomats |publisher=Free Internet Press |date=27 July 2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927235252/https://freeinternetpress.com/story.php?sid=4107 |archivedate=27 September 2007 |df= }} Egyptian diplomatic envoy al-Sherif,{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/4660909.stm|title=Captors kill Egypt envoy to Iraq|publisher=BBC News|date=8 July 2005 | accessdate=5 January 2010}} and four Russian diplomats.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/5118702.stm|title=Russian diplomat deaths confirmed|publisher=BBC News|date=26 June 2006 | accessdate=5 January 2010}} * The February 2006 bombing of the [[al-Askari Mosque]], destroying one of the holiest Shiite shrines, killing over 165 worshipers and igniting [[sectarian strife]] and reprisal killings.Alex Rodriguez, [https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/1068767901.html?dids=1068767901:1068767901&FMT=ABS&type=current Iraqi shrine blast suspect caught] (paid archive), ''The Chicago Tribune'' 29 June 2006. * The publicised killing of several contractors; [[Eugene Armstrong]], [[Jack Hensley]], [[Kenneth Bigley]], Ivaylo Kepov and Georgi Lazov (Bulgarian truck drivers.){{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2004/07/13/bulgarian_iraq040713.html|title=Insurgents kill Bulgarian hostage: Al-Jazeera|publisher=CBC News|date=14 July 2004}} Other non-military personnel murdered include: translator [[Kim Sun-il]], [[Shosei Koda]], [[Fabrizio Quattrocchi]] (Italian), charity worker [[Margaret Hassan]], reconstruction engineer [[Nick Berg]], photographer Salvatore Santoro (Italian){{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/background/iraq/hostages.html#killed |title=Foreign hostages in Iraq |publisher=CBC News |date=22 June 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060807115040/http://www.cbc.ca/news/background/iraq/hostages.html |archivedate=7 August 2006 }} and supply worker [[Seif Adnan Kanaan]] (Iraqi.) Four private armed contractors, Scott Helvenston, Jerko Zovko, Wesley Batalona and Michael Teague, were killed with grenades and small arms fire, their bodies dragged from their vehicles, beaten and set ablaze. Their burned corpses were then dragged through the streets before being hung over a bridge crossing the Euphrates.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/mmedia/apdaily/033104-11v.htm |title=4 Contractors murdered by al Qaeda |work=The Washington Post |date=31 March 2004 |accessdate=23 October 2010}} * Torture or killing of members of the [[New Iraqi Army]],{{cite news |author=Sabrina Tavernise|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/06/19/international/middleeast/19torture.html?ex=1276833600&en=8711248f5a2b9fe6&ei=5088|title=Iraqis Found in Torture House Tell of Brutality of Insurgents|work=The New York Times|date=19 June 2005}} and assassination of civilians associated with the [[Coalition Provisional Authority]], such as [[Fern Holland]], or the [[Iraqi Governing Council]], such as [[Aqila al-Hashimi]] and [[Ezzedine Salim]], or other foreign civilians, such as those from Kenya.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/3920119.stm|title=Iraq kidnappings stun Kenya press|publisher=BBC News|date=23 July 2004 | accessdate=5 January 2010}} ==Public opinion on the war== {{Main|Public opinion on the Iraq War}} ===International opinion=== [[File:London Anti-war demo 2005.jpg|thumb|Protesters on 19 March 2005, in London, where over 150,000 marched]] In a March 2003 [[Gallup (company)|Gallup]] poll, the day after the invasion, 76% of Americans had approved of military action against Iraq.{{cite news |title=Seventy-Two Percent of Americans Support War Against Iraq |url=https://news.gallup.com/poll/8038/seventytwo-percent-americans-support-war-against-iraq.aspx |work=Gallup |date=March 24, 2003}} In a March 2003 [[YouGov]] poll, 54% of Britons supported the military action against Iraq.{{cite news |title=Surveys reveal how we remember opposing the Iraq war - but at the time we supported it |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/surveys-reveal-how-we-remember-not-supporting-war-in-iraq-but-at-the-time-we-did-support-it-10300854.html |work=The Independent |date=5 June 2015}} According to a January 2007 [[BBC World Service]] poll of more than 26,000 people in 25 countries, 73% of the global population disapproved of U.S. handling of the Iraq War.{{cite news |title=World View of U.S. Role Goes from Bad to Worse|publisher=[[BBC World Service]]|date=23 January 2007|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/bsp/hi/pdfs/23_01_07_us_poll.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=23 May 2007}} A September 2007 poll conducted by the BBC found that two-thirds of the world's population believed the U.S. should withdraw its forces from Iraq.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6981553.stm|publisher=BBC News |title=Most people 'want Iraq pull-out'|date=7 September 2007 | accessdate=5 January 2010}} In 2006 it was found that majorities in the UK and Canada believed that the war in Iraq was "unjustified" and – in the UK – were critical of their government's support of U.S. policies in Iraq.{{cite web|url=http://www.icmresearch.co.uk/pdfs/2006_july_guardian_july_poll.pdf |title=Guardian July Poll |date=July 2006 |publisher=ICM Research |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080527234221/http://www.icmresearch.co.uk/pdfs/2006_july_guardian_july_poll.pdf |archivedate=27 May 2008 |df= }} According to polls conducted by the [[Arab American Institute]], four years after the invasion of Iraq, 83% of Egyptians had a negative view of the U.S. role in Iraq; 68% of Saudi Arabians had a negative view; 96% of the Jordanian population had a negative view; 70% of the population of the United Arab Emirates and 76% of the Lebanese population also described their view as negative.{{cite web|last=Zogby |first=James |publisher=[[Arab American Institute]] |date=March 2007 |url=http://www.aaiusa.org/page/-/Polls/2007_poll_four_years_later_arab_opinion.pdf |title=Four Years Later: Arab Opinion Troubled by Consequences of Iraq War |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150128061143/http://www.aaiusa.org/page/-/Polls/2007_poll_four_years_later_arab_opinion.pdf |archivedate=28 January 2015 }} The Pew Global Attitudes Project reports that in 2006 majorities in the [[Netherlands]], (Germany), [[Jordan]], France, [[Lebanon]], Russia, China, Canada, [[Poland]], [[Pakistan]], Spain, [[Indonesia]], [[Turkey]], and [[Morocco]] believed the world was safer before the Iraq War and the toppling of Saddam, while pluralities in the United States and [[India]] believe the world is safer without Saddam Hussein.{{cite web |publisher=Pew Research Center|work=Pew Global Attitudes Project|date=28 February 2006|url=http://pewglobal.org/commentary/display.php?AnalysisID=1002|title=India: Pro-America, Pro-Bush}} ====Iraqi opinion==== [[File:Pleadingforfreedom.jpg|thumb|A woman pleads with an [[Iraqi army]] soldier from 2nd Company, 5th Brigade, 2nd Iraqi Army Division to let a suspected insurgent free during a raid near Tafaria, [[Iraq]]]] Directly after the invasion, polling suggested that a slight majority supported the U.S. invasion.[https://archive.is/20130126110354/http://www.indianexpress.com/storyOld.php?storyId=22949 Most Iraqis in Baghdad welcome US: NDTV poll] The Indian Express Polls conducted between 2005 and 2007 showed 31–37% of Iraqis wanted U.S. and other Coalition forces to withdraw once security was restored and that 26–35% wanted immediate withdrawal instead.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldpublicopinion.org/pipa/pdf/sep06/Iraq_Sep06_rpt.pdf |title=The Iraqi Public on the U.S. Presence and the Future of Iraq |format=PDF |publisher=World Public Opinion |date=27 September 2006 |accessdate=23 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160824163145/http://www.worldpublicopinion.org/pipa/pdf/sep06/Iraq_Sep06_rpt.pdf |archivedate=24 August 2016 |df= }}[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/shared/bsp/hi/pdfs/19_03_07_iraqpollnew.pdf Iraq Poll] conducted by [[D3 Systems|D3 Systems]] for the BBC, ABC News, ARD German TV and USA Today. More than 2,000 people were questioned in more than 450 neighbourhoods and villages across all 18 provinces of Iraq between 25 February and 5 March 2007. The margin of error is + or – 2.5%.[http://www.globalpolicy.org/security/issues/iraq/poll/2007/0806oildevt.htm Iraqis Oppose Oil Development Plans, Poll Finds (6 August 2007)] (Oil Change International, Institute for Policy Studies, War on Want, PLATFORM and Global Policy Forum) Despite a majority having previously been opposed to the U.S. presence, 60% of Iraqis opposed American troops leaving directly prior to withdrawal, with 51% saying withdrawal would have a negative effect.[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iPXciunRc2PXMN3VHyMfi1DIsIuQ Most Iraqis in Baghdad welcome US: NDTV poll] The Indian Express {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111222200328/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iPXciunRc2PXMN3VHyMfi1DIsIuQ |date=22 December 2011 }}[http://www.arabtimesonline.com/NewsDetails/tabid/96/smid/414/ArticleID/158748/reftab/36/Default.aspx US under 50,000 – Iraqis 'down' on drawdown] Arab Times {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150221193808/http://www.arabtimesonline.com/NewsDetails/tabid/96/smid/414/ArticleID/158748/reftab/36/Default.aspx |date=21 February 2015 }} In 2006, a poll conducted on the Iraqi public revealed that 52% of the ones polled said Iraq was going in the right direction and 61% claimed it was worth ousting Saddam Hussein. In a March 2007 BBC poll, 82% of Iraqis expressed a lack of confidence in coalition forces based in Iraq.{{cite news |title=Iraq poll March 2007: In graphics |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6451841.stm |work=BBC |date=19 March 2007}} ==Relation to the Global War on Terrorism== {{Main|Iraq War and U.S. Global War on Terror}} {{Further|Criticism of the War on Terrorism|Saddam Hussein and al-Qaeda|Saddam Hussein and al-Qaeda timeline}} Though explicitly stating that Iraq had "nothing" to do with 9/11,{{Cite book |author= [[Office of the Federal Register]] |year= 2010 |title= Administration of George W. Bush, 2006: Book II, July 1 to December 31, 2006 |series= [[Public Papers of the Presidents]] |location= Washington, DC |publisher= United States Government Printing Office |page= [https://books.google.com/books?id=ozUnYqCDj9UC&pg=PA1542 1542] |display-authors=etal}} erstwhile President George W. Bush consistently referred to the Iraq war as "the central front in the [[War on Terrorism|War on Terror]]", and argued that if the United States pulled out of Iraq, "terrorists will follow us here".{{cite web |last=Bush|first=President George W.|publisher=The White House|date=9 September 2003|url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2003/09/20030909.html|title=A Central Front in the War on Terror}}{{cite news|last=Garamone |first=Jim |publisher=American Forces Press Service |date=19 September 2002 |url=http://www.defenselink.mil/news/Sep2002/n09192002_200209194.html |title=Iraq Part of Global War on Terrorism, Rumsfeld Says |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929203848/http://www.defenselink.mil/news/Sep2002/n09192002_200209194.html |archivedate=29 September 2007 }}{{cite news |last=Bush|first=President George W.|url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2006/08/20060821.html|title=Press Conference by the President|date=21 August 2006|work=Peace in the Middle East|publisher=The White House}} While other proponents of the war regularly echoed this assertion, as the conflict dragged on, members of the U.S. Congress, the U.S. public, and even U.S. troops questioned the connection between Iraq and the fight against anti-U.S. terrorism. In particular, a consensus developed among intelligence experts that the Iraq war actually increased terrorism. [[Counterterrorism]] expert [[Rohan Gunaratna]] frequently referred to the invasion of Iraq as a "fatal mistake".{{cite journal|last=Gunaratna|first=Rohan|title=The Post-Madrid Face of Al Qaeda|journal=Washington Quarterly|volume=27|issue=3|date=Summer 2004|url=http://www.mitpressjournals.org/doi/abs/10.1162/016366004323090278|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150128070821/http://www.mitpressjournals.org/doi/abs/10.1162/016366004323090278|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2015-01-28|doi=10.1162/016366004323090278|page=98}} London's [[International Institute for Strategic Studies]] concluded in 2004 that the occupation of Iraq had become "a potent global recruitment pretext" for [[Mujahideen]] and that the invasion "galvanised" al-Qaeda and "perversely inspired insurgent violence" there.{{cite news|last=Sengupta |first=Kim |title=Occupation Made World Less Safe, Pro-War Institute Says |work=[[The Independent]] |date=26 May 2004 |url=http://www.commondreams.org/headlines04/0526-05.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060920050852/http://www.commondreams.org/headlines04/0526-05.htm |archivedate=20 September 2006 }} The U.S. [[National Intelligence Council]] concluded in a January 2005 report that the war in Iraq had become a breeding ground for a new generation of terrorists; David Low, the national intelligence officer for transnational threats, indicated that the report concluded that the war in Iraq provided terrorists with "a training ground, a recruitment ground, the opportunity for enhancing technical skills ... There is even, under the best scenario, over time, the likelihood that some of the jihadists who are not killed there will, in a sense, go home, wherever home is, and will therefore disperse to various other countries." The Council's chairman [[Robert Hutchings]] said, "At the moment, Iraq is a magnet for international terrorist activity."{{cite news |last=Priest|first=Dana|title=Iraq New Terror Breeding Ground|work=The Washington Post|date=14 January 2005|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A7460-2005Jan13.html}} And the 2006 [[National Intelligence Estimate]], which outlined the considered judgment of all 16 U.S. intelligence agencies, held that "The Iraq conflict has become the 'cause célèbre' for jihadists, breeding a deep resentment of U.S. involvement in the [[Muslim world]] and cultivating supporters for the global jihadist movement."{{cite press release|title=Declassified Key Judgments of the National Intelligence Estimate "Trends in Global Terrorism: Implications for the United States" |publisher=Office of the Director of National Intelligence |date=April 2006 |url=http://www.dni.gov/press_releases/Declassified_NIE_Key_Judgments.pdf |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060930220648/http://www.dni.gov/press_releases/Declassified_NIE_Key_Judgments.pdf |archivedate=30 September 2006 }} ==Foreign involvement== ===Role of Saudi Arabia and non-Iraqis=== {{see also|Saudi Arabia and terrorism}} {{bar box |title= Origins of suicide bombers in Iraq 2003–2007 |titlebar=#DDD |float= right |left1= Nationality |right2= |width= 300px |bars= {{bar pixel|[[Saudi Arabia]]|red|53}} {{bar pixel|[[Iraq]]|orange|18}} {{bar pixel|Italy|blue|8}} {{bar pixel|[[Syria]]|blue|8}} {{bar pixel|[[Kuwait]]|blue|7}} {{bar pixel|[[Jordan]]|blue|4}} {{bar pixel|*Other|blue|26}} |caption=*Three each from [[Egypt]], [[Libya]], [[Tunisia]], [[Turkey]], [[Yemen]]; two each from [[Belgium]], France, Spain; one each from Britain, [[Lebanon]], [[Morocco]], [[Sudan]] }} According to studies, most of the suicide bombers in [[Iraq]] are foreigners, especially [[Saudi]]s.{{cite news |last=Bernstein-Wax|first=Jessica|title=Studies: Suicide bombers in Iraq are mostly foreigners|url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2007/08/08/18791/studies-suicide-bombers-in-iraq.html |publisher=[[McClatchy Newspapers]]|date=8 August 2007}}{{cite news |last=Glasser|first=Susan B.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/05/14/AR2005051401270.html|title='Martyrs' In Iraq Mostly Saudis|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=15 May 2005}}See also: Hafez, Mohammed M. [https://web.archive.org/web/20140222201450/http://www.powells.com/biblio?inkey=65-9781601270047-2 ''Suicide Bomber in Iraq'']. United States Institute of Peace Press. {{ISBN|1601270046}}. === Role of China and Russia === As an ally of Iraq, Russia was opposed to the invasion of Iraq. The foreign ministers of Russia, France and Germany made a joint declaration that they will "not allow" passage of a [[United Nations Security Council and the Iraq War|UN Security Council]] resolution authorising war against Iraq. Russia gave information to Saddam's government about the Bush administration's plans. The information included troop deployments, equipment, and their locations.{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/russia-provided-iraq-with-details-of-the-uss-planned-invasion-in-2003-2016-4|title=Russia provided Iraq with details of the US's planned invasion in 2003|work=Business Insider|access-date=2017-10-28|language=en}} Though the Chinese and Russian governments opposed the Iraq War, both China and Russia have benefited from the Iraq War while suffering none of the losses incurred by the countries that invaded. Two of the biggest Iraqi oil contracts went to China and Russia,{{cite web|url=http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1948787,00.html|title=U.S. Companies Shut Out as Iraq Auctions Its Oil Fields|first=Vivienne|last=Walt|date=19 December 2009|publisher=|accessdate=26 February 2017|via=content.time.com}} while the war itself allowed China to present itself as an alternative source of investment to the United States.{{Cite web|url=http://www.rubincenter.org/2014/09/ten-years-later-who-won-the-iraq-war-the-us-or-china/|title=TEN YEARS LATER: WHO WON THE IRAQ WAR, THE US OR CHINA?|website=www.rubincenter.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-28}} ===Iranian involvement=== Although some military intelligence analysts have concluded there is no concrete evidence, U.S. Major General Rick Lynch has claimed that Iran has provided training, weapons, money, and intelligence to Shiite insurgents in Iraq and that up to 150 Iranian intelligence agents, plus members of the [[Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps|Iranian Revolutionary Guard]] are believed to be active in Iraq at any given time.{{cite news |title=Troops Authorized to Kill Iranian Operatives in Iraq |first=Dafna |last=Linzer |date=26 January 2007 |page=A.1 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/01/25/AR2007012502199.html |work=[[The Washington Post]]}}{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/08/19/AR2007081901394.html |title=Iran Trains Militiamen Inside Iraq, U.S. Says |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=20 August 2007|accessdate=23 October 2010 |first=Megan |last=Greenwell}} Lynch thinks that members of the IRGC's [[Quds Force]] have trained members of the Qazali terror network in explosives technology and also provided the network with arms, munitions, and military advisors. Many explosive devices, including improvised explosives ([[Improvised explosive device|IEDs]]) and explosively-formed projectiles (EFPs), used by insurgents are claimed by Lynch to be Iranian-made or designed. According to two unnamed U.S. officials, [[the Pentagon]] is examining the possibility that the [[Karbala provincial headquarters raid]], in which insurgents managed to infiltrate an American base, kill five U.S. soldiers, wound three, and destroy three humvees before fleeing, was supported by Iranians. In a speech on {{Nowrap|31 January 2007}}, Iraqi Prime Minister [[Nouri al-Maliki]] stated that Iran was supporting attacks against Coalition forces in Iraq{{cite news |title=Al-Maliki: Iraq won't be battleground for U.S., Iran |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/meast/01/31/iraq.main/ |publisher=CNN |date=31 January 2007 |accessdate=31 January 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070202013010/http://edition.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/meast/01/31/iraq.main/ |archivedate=2 February 2007}} and some Iraqis suspect that the raid may have been perpetrated by the Quds Force in retaliation for the detention of five Iranian officials by U.S. forces in the northern Iraqi city of [[Irbil]] on {{Nowrap|11 January}}.{{cite news |title=Iran involvement suspected in Karbala compound attack |url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/meast/01/30/iraq.main/index.html |publisher=CNN |date=31 January 2007 |accessdate=31 January 2007}}{{cite news |first=Robert |last=Baer |authorlink=Robert Baer |title=Are the Iranians Out for Revenge? |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1583523,00.html?cnn=yes |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=30 January 2007 |accessdate=31 January 2007}} In 2011, U.S. ambassador [[James Franklin Jeffrey]] stated "that Iranian proxies accounted for roughly a quarter of US combat casualties in Iraq—around 1,100 deaths and many thousands more injuries."{{cite news |last=Chulov|first=Martin|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jul/28/qassem-suleimani-iran-iraq-influence|title=Qassem Suleimani: the Iranian general 'secretly running' Iraq|newspaper=The Guardian|date=28 July 2011|accessdate=2014-08-20}} ==See also== {{Portal |Iraq |Military of the United States |War |2000s|2010s}} {{div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[July 12, 2007, Baghdad airstrike]] (associated with [[WikiLeaks]] in 2010) * [[Iraq–United States relations]] * [[List of wars by death toll]] * [[National Network to End the War Against Iraq]] * [[Foreign interventions by the United States]] * [[Protests against the Iraq War]] * [[United Nations Security Council and the Iraq War]] * [[United States military casualties of war]] * [[Iran–Saudi Arabia proxy conflict]] * ''[[The Iraq War: A Historiography of Wikipedia Changelogs]]'' {{div col end}} ==Footnotes== {{Reflist|group=nb}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |last=Bellavia|first=David|title=House to House: An Epic Memoir of War|year=2007|publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]]|isbn=978-1416574712|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=74DRCVfzqkgC&dq=House+to+House:+an+Epic+of+Urban+Warfare&source=gbs_navlinks_s}} * {{cite news |author=Dexter Filkins |title=General Principles: How good was David Petraeus? {{Use British English|date=January 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox person |name = Jade Goody |image = Goody.jpg |caption = Goody at the [[Boleyn Ground]], in May 2007 |birth_name = Jade Cerisa Lorraine Goody |birth_date = {{Birth date|1981|6|5|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Bermondsey]], [[London]], England |death_date = {{death date and age|2009|3|22|1981|5|6|df=y}} |death_place = [[Upshire]], Waltham Abbey, [[Essex]], England |death_cause = [[Cervical cancer]] |resting_place = [[Epping Forest]], Essex, England |nationality =British |ethnicity = |occupation = |years_active = 2002–2009 |spouse = {{marriage|[[Jack Tweed]]|2009}}[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/4953389/Jade-Goody-is-christened-with-sons-at-hospital-chapel.html "Jade Goody is christened with sons at hospital chapel"], ''The Daily Telegraph'', 9 March 2009; retrieved 22 March 2009. |partner = [[Jeff Brazier]] (2002–04)
[[Ryan Amoo]] (2005) |children = 2 |parents = [[Jackiey Budden]]
Andrew Goody }} '''Jade Cerisa Lorraine Tweed''' ({{née}} '''Goody'''; 5 June 1981 – 22 March 2009){{cite news|author=Sunder Katwala |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2007/jan/19/post955 |title=The education of Jade Goody |work=guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date=19 January 2007 |accessdate=22 February 2009 | location=London}}{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/entertainmentNews/idUKTRE52L08B20090322 |title=TV star Jade Goody dies of cancer |work=Reuters |date=22 March 2009}} was an [[English people|English]] reality-television personality. She entered the public spotlight in the [[Big Brother 3 (UK)|third series]] of the then-[[Channel 4]] programme ''[[Big Brother (UK)|Big Brother]]'' in 2002, an appearance which led to her own TV programs and the introduction of her products after her eviction from the show.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.co.uk/channel/mtvuk/news/470372-leona-lewis-to-launch-perfume |title=Leona Lewis To Launch Perfume |website=Mtv.co.uk |date=15 January 2009 |accessdate=22 February 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090118194832/http://www.mtv.co.uk/channel/mtvuk/news/470372-leona-lewis-to-launch-perfume|archivedate=18 January 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/6276279.stm |title=Profile: Jade Goody |work=BBC News |accessdate=22 February 2009 | date=20 February 2009}} Immediately criticised by the British press for her perceived lack of decorum and intelligence,{{cite book|author=Holmes, Su: Jermyn, Deborah|date=2003|title=Understanding Reality Television|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=qyK20eYiz3oC&pg=PA125&lpg=PA125&dq=%22jade+goody%22+%22notoriously+unpopular%22&source=bl&ots=9lWKN60Pli&sig=5D11I10qBvMXEfy7E6Hz9tdHuYc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiTguaThbDSAhXoIsAKHSWzANIQ6AEIKDAC#v=onepage&q=%22jade%20goody%22%20%22notoriously%20unpopular%22&f=false|publisher=[[Routledge]]|page=125|isbn=978-0415317955}} Goody was dubbed by multiple outlets as "the most hated woman in Britain".{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/the-jade-goody-phenomenon-5542408.html|title=The Jade Goody phenomenon|date=9 January 2007|website=[[The Independent]]|access-date=19 February 2017}} The country's celebrity magazines were less derisive, publishing reports of her affable nature and competent school performance from those who knew her. Public opinion of Goody reached its most negative in January 2007, however, when she was accused of [[Celebrity Big Brother racism controversy|racially bullying]] [[Indian people|Indian]] actress [[Shilpa Shetty]] while appearing as a housemate on ''[[Celebrity Big Brother 5]]''.{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/Why-Jade-Goody-matters/articleshow/4360932.cms?|title=Why Jade Goody matters|date=5 April 2009|website=[[The Times of India]]|access-date=19 February 2017}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2007/jan/20/raceintheuk.bigbrother |title=Jade evicted as poll reveals public anger with Channel 4 |work=The Guardian |accessdate=22 February 2009 | location=London | first=Karen | last=McVeigh | date=22 January 2007}} Following her eviction, Goody made a number of apologies, but continued to garner negative public reactions.{{cite news|title=Socialite recognised for her true talent |url=http://www.nowmagazine.co.uk/celeb_news/SEE_VIDEO_Paris_Hilton_named_Most_Pointless_Celebrity_article_165779.html |work=[[Now (UK magazine)|Now magazine]] |date=1 December 2007 |accessdate=13 April 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071208174743/http://www.nowmagazine.co.uk/celeb_news/SEE_VIDEO_Paris_Hilton_named_Most_Pointless_Celebrity_article_165779.html |archivedate=8 December 2007 }}{{cite news|title=Jade Goody and Pete Doherty top worst dinner party guest list|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/entertainment/entertainment-news/2008/04/10/jade-goody-and-pete-doherty-top-worst-dinner-party-guest-list-86908-20378005/ |work=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]] |date=10 April 2008|accessdate=11 April 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080411015829/http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/entertainment/entertainment-news/2008/04/10/jade-goody-and-pete-doherty-top-worst-dinner-party-guest-list-86908-20378005/ |archivedate = 11 April 2008}} In August 2008, Goody appeared on the Indian version of ''Big Brother'', ''[[Bigg Boss (season 2)|Bigg Boss]]'',{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2008/aug/14/bigbrother.television |title=Jade Goody to join Indian Big Brother |work=The Guardian |accessdate=22 February 2009 | location=London | first=Leigh | last=Holmwood | date=14 August 2008}} but left the show early and returned to the UK after learning that she had [[cervical cancer]].{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/jade-goody-diagnosed-with-cancer-902060.html |title=Jade Goody diagnosed with cancer |work=The Independent |date=19 August 2008 |accessdate=22 February 2009 | location=London}} By February 2009, the cancer had [[metastasis|metastasized]], and Goody was [[terminal illness|terminally ill]].{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/SHOWBIZ/02/16/jade.goody.big.brother.cancer/ |title=Big Brother star to wed after terminal cancer confirmed |work=CNN |date=16 February 2009 |accessdate=22 February 2009}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/feb/16/jade-goody-cancer-max-clifford-television |title=Jade Goody wedding may be televised, hints Max Clifford |work=The Guardian |accessdate=22 February 2009 | location=London | first=Ben | last=Dowell | date=16 February 2009}} She married fellow ''Celebrity Big Brother'' contestant Jack Tweed on 22 February 2009,{{cite news |url=http://women.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/women/celebrity/article5786661.ece |title=video: Jade Goody gets married amid tears, cheers and a £700,000 OK! magazine deal |work=Women.timesonline.co.uk |date= 23 February 2009|accessdate=21 March 2009 | location=London | first=Patrick | last=Foster}} and died one month later, in the early hours of 22 March 2009, at the age of 27. Public opinion of Goody had softened by the time of her death. [[Sky Living]] broadcast five tribute shows from 2009 to 2012, documenting her life from early childhood through her rise to fame and her final months. The last episode of ''Big Brother'' on [[Channel 4]] featured a 15-minute tribute to Goody, praising her as the ultimate ''Big Brother'' contestant. She was one of several people to appear on the front cover of the final edition of ''[[News of the World]]'' on 10 July 2011. ==Early life== Goody was born in [[Bermondsey]], [[London]], to [[Jackiey Budden]] and Andrew Goody. Her father was a [[substance dependence|drug addict]] and habitual criminal who spent time in prison, including a four-year term for robbery. He and Budden separated when Goody was two; estranged from his daughter while Budden raised her, he died of a drug overdose in 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.nowmagazine.co.uk/celebrity-news/271497/jade-goody-visits-dad-s-grave-for-first-time/1/ |title=Jade Goody visits dad's grave for first time |publisher=Now Magazine |date=27 August 2008 |accessdate=22 February 2009}} At the age of 5, Goody made an uncredited appearance as a primary school student in the 1986 television film ''[[List of London's Burning episodes#The TV Movie (1986)|London's Burning]]'' (filmed in her home town), which spawned [[London's Burning (TV series)|the television series of the same name]]. Before entering the ''Big Brother'' house, Goody, a [[Registered Dental Nurse|dental nurse]], lived in [[Upshire]], Waltham Abbey, [[Essex]].{{cite web|url=http://www.findmypast.com/BirthsMarriagesDeaths.jsp |title=Births and Deaths England and Wales 1984–2006 |publisher=Findmypast.com |date= |accessdate=31 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090831050858/http://www.findmypast.com/BirthsMarriagesDeaths.jsp |archivedate=31 August 2009 |df=dmy-all }} ==Career== ===2002–2003: ''Big Brother 3''=== When Goody appeared on ''[[Big Brother 2002 (UK)|Big Brother 3]]'', she was ridiculed by the British [[Tabloid journalism|tabloid]] press for her lack of general knowledge.{{cite news|title=The Jade Goody Phenomenon |work=The Independent |url=http://news.independent.co.uk/people/profiles/article2137700.ece |accessdate=3 October 2007 |location=London |date=9 January 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930211538/http://news.independent.co.uk/people/profiles/article2137700.ece |archivedate=30 September 2007 |df=dmy-all }} She thought the English city of [[Cambridge]] was in London;{{cite news |first=Polly |last=Hudson |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/top-stories/2008/08/23/life-knocks-jade-goody-and-kerry-katona-down-but-they-always-bounce-back-115875-20707964/ |title=Life knocks Jade Goody and Kerry Katona down but they always bounce back |work=Mirror.co.uk}} when told that it was in [[East Anglia]], she assumed East Anglia was outside Britain and referred to it as "East Angula".{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/tv_and_radio/2055968.stm |title=Jade's wit and wisdom |work=BBC News |date=26 July 2002 |accessdate=22 February 2009}} Goody thought that [[Rio de Janeiro]] was a person, not a city; that Portugal was part of Spain; that [[St George's Cross]] was the flag of London, not [[flag of England|England]]; that [[Aberdeen]] was not in Scotland, and that the United States was not an [[English-speaking country]]. She was also criticised by the tabloid press during her time in the ''Big Brother'' house for [[backstabbing]] and an evening when she cavorted drunk and naked.{{cite web|url=http://www.bigbrotheronline.co.uk/celebritybigbrother5/contestants/Jade_Goody.htm |title=Jade Goody Big Brother Contestant Profile – Celebrity Big Brother 5 UK |publisher=Bigbrotheronline.co.uk |accessdate=22 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090221211159/http://www.bigbrotheronline.co.uk/celebritybigbrother5/contestants/Jade_Goody.htm |archivedate=21 February 2009 |df=dmy-all }} ===2003–2006: Initial fame and Sky Living series=== Goody appeared in her own reality TV shows{{cite web |url=http://entertainment.uk.msn.com/tv/news/Article.aspx?cp-documentid=13034874 |title=Jade Goody shows all on TV show |website=-MSN UK |date=20 January 2009 |accessdate=22 February 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} and, regularly, in celebrity, [[trivia]] and gossip-oriented women's magazines such as ''[[Heat (magazine)|Heat]]'' and ''[[OK!]]''. She participated in the 2006 [[London Marathon]] but did not finish (collapsing after {{convert|34|km|mi|abbr=on}} of the {{convert|42.195|km|mi|adj=on}} course), and recovered overnight at the [[Royal London Hospital]].{{cite web|url=http://showbiz.sky.com/Jades-Marathon-Hell |title=Jade's Marathon Hell |website=Sky Showbiz |date=24 April 2006 |accessdate=22 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090330115005/http://showbiz.sky.com/Jades-Marathon-Hell |archivedate=30 March 2009 |df=dmy-all }} Before the marathon, Goody described her preparations to [[celebrity chef|TV chef]] [[Gordon Ramsay]]: "I've been eating [[curry]], [[Chinese cuisine|Chinese]] and [[alcoholic beverage|drinking]]." She said afterwards, "I don't really understand miles. I didn't actually know how far it was going to be ... I didn't want to let everyone down." Goody raised [[pound sterling|£]]565.20 for her chosen charity, the [[National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children]].{{cite web|author=National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children |url=http://www.justgiving.com/jadegoody |title=NSPCC |publisher=Justgiving.com |date=23 April 2006 |accessdate=31 October 2011}} On 16 February 2004, Goody entered the ''[[Back to Reality (TV series)|Back to Reality]]'' house on [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]]. The series, similar to ''Big Brother'', featured contestants from other reality shows such as ''Big Brother'' and ''[[I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here! (UK TV series)|I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here!]]''. She was evicted on Day 20. In 2005 Goody created and introduced her own fragrance (Shh...) with distributor Jigsaw ESL, who gave its exclusive rights to [[Superdrug]]. Shh... became Superdrug's third-bestselling fragrance, behind [[Kylie Minogue]]'s and [[Victoria Beckham]]'s.[http://jigsawesl.com/brands/celeb/jade-goody/ ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121027052848/http://jigsawesl.com/brands/celeb/jade-goody/ |date=27 October 2012 }}{{cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Business/Still-Controversial-Reality-TV-Star-Jade-Goody-Launches-New-Perfume/Article/200807415060385 |title=Still Controversial: Reality TV Star Jade Goody Launches New Perfume |work=Sky News |date= |accessdate=22 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090301190225/http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Business/Still-Controversial-Reality-TV-Star-Jade-Goody-Launches-New-Perfume/Article/200807415060385 |archivedate=1 March 2009 |df=dmy-all }} On 2 May 2006, ''Jade: My Autobiography'' was published. ===2007–2008: ''Celebrity Big Brother'' 5=== {{main article|Celebrity Big Brother racism controversy}} On 5 January 2007 Goody, her boyfriend Jack Tweed and her mother entered the house for ''[[Celebrity Big Brother 5 (UK)|Celebrity Big Brother 5]]''. She had just placed 25th in a ''Heat'' poll of the world's most influential people, with lifetime earnings of £8 million. Goody was told that she and her family (later joined by [[Jermaine Jackson]], [[Shilpa Shetty]] and [[Ken Russell]]) would live luxuriously in the main house, with the eight remaining celebrities living in the house next door as their servants. She was not told that she and her new family faced an eviction in which the public chose whom to keep. Goody's mother was the first to be evicted, on 10 January 2007.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/6249601.stm |work=BBC News |title=Jackiey first Big Brother evictee | date=11 January 2007 | accessdate=26 March 2010}} A number of complaints were received by British broadcasting regulator [[Ofcom]] about the behaviour of [[Jo O'Meara]], [[Danielle Lloyd]] and Goody towards housemate Shilpa Shetty.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/6265127.stm |work=BBC News |title=Ofcom probes Big Brother 'racism' | date=16 January 2007 | accessdate=26 March 2010}}{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/6268401.stm |work=BBC News |title=Big Brother row reaches Commons | date=16 January 2007 | accessdate=26 March 2010}} By 20 January Ofcom received more than 44,500 complaints from the public (a record at the time),{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/6281223.stm |work=BBC News |title=I'm not racist, says TV's Goody | date=20 January 2007 | accessdate=26 March 2010}}{{cite news | title=Big Brother sponsor suspends deal |work=BBC News |date=18 January 2007 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/6274881.stm |accessdate=24 January 2007}} and Channel 4 received an additional 3,000 complaints.{{cite news|work=The Guardian |title=Racism, ratings and reality TV: now Big Brother creates a diplomatic incident |url=http://politics.guardian.co.uk/foreignaffairs/story/0,,1992924,00.html |accessdate=18 January 2007 |location=London |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070120145029/http://politics.guardian.co.uk/foreignaffairs/story/0%2C%2C1992924%2C00.html |archivedate=20 January 2007 |first1=Owen |last1=Gibson |first2=Vikram |last2=Dodd |first3=Randeep |last3=Ramesh |date=18 January 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} Among Goody's remarks were, "I've seen how she goes in and out of people's arseholes" and Shetty "makes [her] skin crawl".{{cite news|url=http://showbiz.sky.com/showbiz/article/0,,50001-1247791,00.html |work=Sky Showbiz |title=Has Jade Lost It? |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013111613/http://showbiz.sky.com/showbiz/article/0%2C%2C50001-1247791%2C00.html |archivedate=13 October 2007 |df=dmy-all }}[http://www.ibnlive.com/videos/31466/slurs-against-shilpa-continue-on-show.html CNN – IBN News] – ''slurs against shilpa continue on show 'racism''' She also called Shetty "Shilpa Fuckawalla" and "[[Papadum|Shilpa Poppadom]]". Other, unbroadcast incidents of racism were later alleged,{{cite news|first=Owen |last=Gibson |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2007/may/25/ofcom.broadcasting|title=C4 to air Big Brother racism apologies |work=The Guardian|date=27 May 2007|accessdate=21 February 2009 | location=London}} including a late-night limerick game between O'Meara, Lloyd, Goody and Tweed in which the word "[[List of ethnic slurs#Paki|Paki]]" was implied but not said.{{cite news|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article1837932.ece |title=Big Brother in racism 'cover-up' |work=Times Online |date=25 May 2007 |accessdate=22 February 2009 |location=London |first=Adam |last=Sherwin |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615122803/http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article1837932.ece |archivedate=15 June 2011 }} Goody allegedly wondered aloud if Lloyd used "the P-word", and referred to Shetty as "Shilpa Pashwa whoever you fucking are". The incident triggered an international outcry, receiving extensive coverage in the Indian media (where [[Gordon Brown]], then British [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]], was visiting at the time). Brown condemned the programme for damaging the impression of Britain as a country of tolerance.{{cite news |url=http://media.guardian.co.uk/site/story/0,,1992450,00.html |title=Big Brother row goes global |work=The Guardian |date=17 January 2007 | location=London | first=Chris | last=Tryhorn | accessdate=5 May 2010}} In a 17 January statement, Channel 4 defended the programme against charges "of overt racism or racial abuse".{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/6272585.stm |work=BBC News |title=Channel 4 denies Brother 'racism' | date=18 January 2007 | accessdate=26 March 2010}} Goody was evicted from the ''Big Brother'' house on 19 January 2007, receiving 82 percent of the vote when she was up against Shetty.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/6283447.stm |title=Jade 'faces fight to save career' |work=BBC News |date=20 January 2007 |accessdate=22 February 2009}} [[Channel 4]] prevented crowds from gathering outside the house, and cancelled her scheduled press conference.{{cite web |url=http://www.ndtv.com/template/template.asp?template=racismrow&slug=Shilpa+stays+on+in+%3Ci%3EBig+Brother%3C%2Fi%3E&id=21207&callid=0&category=National |title=Shilpa Shetty stays on in Big Brother}}{{Dead link|date=October 2011}} In an interview with [[Davina McCall]] shortly afterwards, Goody said she was "disgusted with [her]self" after seeing a video of the alleged bullying.Celebrity Big Brother Live, 19 January 2007 on Channel 4 Her much-publicised return to the Big Brother house was called "a terrible decision" by publicist [[Max Clifford]]: "It looks like she has ruined a very lucrative career".{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/low/entertainment/6276279.stm |title=Profile: Jade Goody |work=BBC News |date=19 January 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070302144253/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/low/entertainment/6276279.stm |archivedate=2 March 2007}} At this time Goody was a supporter of the anti-bullying charity [[Act Against Bullying]], which dropped her.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/cbbcnews/hi/newsid_6260000/newsid_6267600/6267675.stm |title=Bullying charity drops Jade Goody |publisher=BBC |work=CBBC Newsround |date=16 January 2007 |accessdate=22 February 2009}} In an interview with the ''[[Daily Star (United Kingdom)|Daily Star]]'', Goody said that her abuse of Shetty ruined her girl-next-door image. Although Shetty did not lodge an official complaint about racist behaviour with ''Big Brother'', her allegations compelled police to investigate the possible classification of her treatment as "[[inciting ethnic hatred|racial hatred]]" under Part III of the [[Public Order Act 1986]]. In a statement, the [[Hertfordshire Constabulary|Hertfordshire police]] said that it was
 ... investigating allegations of racist behaviour in the ''Big Brother'' house and will be conducting enquiries, including a review of the tapes. We will continue to liaise with Ofcom and with Endemol, whom we have strongly encouraged to ensure that any form of behaviour that could raise similar concerns, does not occur. We will continue to closely monitor the situation over the next few days. Hertfordshire Constabulary will not tolerate racism in any form and is taking these allegations seriously. The constabulary has experience of investigating and resolving incidents in the ''Big Brother'' house in past seasons.{{cite news|last=Dodd|first=Vikram|url=http://media.guardian.co.uk/broadcast/story/0,,1993588,00.html|title=Shilpa abuse a "racial incident"|date=18 January 2007|publisher=Media Guardian|accessdate=14 July 2009 | location=London}}
According to a Channel 4 spokeswoman, ''Big Brother'' intervened so the contestants would "realise that what they have said has been misconstrued in the house". The idea, she said, was to allow the housemates "to explain themselves" to their fellow contestants.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/6279363.stm |title=Are housemates aware of race row? |date=19 January 2007 |publisher=BBC |accessdate=19 January 2007 |first=Mark |last=Savage}} This was followed by a series of apologies to Shetty from the housemates, and her belief that Goody was not a racist: "I don't feel there was any racial discrimination happening from Jade's end ... I think that there are a lot of insecurities from her end but it's definitely not racial".{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/6274881.stm |title=Big Brother sponsor suspends deal |date= 18 January 2007 |work=BBC News}} However, Shetty was unaware of all the alleged insults (often made behind her back). Channel 4 was rebuked by Ofcom, which received more than 54,000 complaints, for its handling of the scandal.[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2007/may/25/ofcom.broadcasting C4 to air Big Brother racism apologies | Media | The Guardian] Goody initially denied that her comments were racist: "She is Indian, thinking of an Indian name and only thing I could think of was Indian food. Wasn't racial at all. It was not to offend any Indian out there."{{cite news|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/entertainment/filmandtv/s/233/233670_celeb_bb_jade_calls_housemate_shilpa_poppadom.html |title=Celeb BB: Jade calls housemate 'Shilpa Fuckawhalia, Shilpa Poppadom' |work=Manchester Evening News |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070120171306/http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/entertainment/filmandtv/s/233/233670_celeb_bb_jade_calls_housemate_shilpa_poppadom.html |archivedate=20 January 2007 }} On a later trip to India she apologised for her behaviour, admitting that her remarks to Shetty could be seen as racist. In a video on the [[BBC News]] website, Goody said:
I know that things that I don't think are necessarily racist ... could be ... And I am sincerely sorry for the pain and hurt I've caused to Shilpa's family. I am wrong ... I am wrong and I know that my words and my actions were wrong and I'm not trying to justify that in any way – I am wrong, and the people who have complained are not wrong. They're just insulted by me and I completely take that criticism.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/6400689.stm |title=Jade Goody says sorry to Indians |date=27 February 2007|publisher=BBC News |accessdate=19 September 2008}}
===2008–2009: Return to the public eye and final projects before death=== '''''Bigg Boss''''' Goody said in April 2008 that she planned to introduce her second fragrance line, Controversial.{{cite web|author=Rod Liddle |url=http://www.spectator.co.uk/features/3345976/jade-goody-reminds-us-how-arbitrary-is-success-and-how-close-to-death-we-are/ |title=Jade Goody reminds us how arbitrary is success and how close to death we are |publisher=The Spectator |date=11 February 2009 |accessdate=10 September 2013}} In mid-2008 she appeared in the Indian version of ''Big Brother'', ''[[Bigg Boss (Hindi season 2)|Bigg Boss]]'', at a rumoured salary of £100,000.{{cite web|url=http://uk.tv.yahoo.com/18082008/19/jade-goody-joins-indian-big-brother.html |title=Jade Goody joins Indian Big Brother |date=18 August 2008 |publisher=Yahoo. UK |accessdate=15 March 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716162137/http://uk.tv.yahoo.com/18082008/19/jade-goody-joins-indian-big-brother.html |archivedate=16 July 2011 }}{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/2583081/Jade-Goody-told-she-has-cancer-on-Big-Brother-in-India.html|title=Jade Goody told she has cancer on Big Brother in India|last=Salter |first=Jessica |date=20 August 2008|work=The Telegraph |accessdate=15 March 2009 | location=London}} Goody entered the house on 17 August, saying in her opening [[videotape]] that the incident with Shetty was "in the past" and she was "not proud of it". Two days into the show she was diagnosed with [[cervical cancer]] and immediately withdrew, flying home to England. Scenes of Goody learning her diagnosis were not broadcast in India. '''''Living With Jade Goody''''' A reality-television documentary, ''Living With Jade Goody'', was shown in September 2008 as part of the ''Living With...'' series on [[Living TV]].{{cite web|url=http://www.livingtv.co.uk/shows/living-with-jade-goody.php |title=Jade Goody – Shows – Virgin Media |publisher=Livingtv.co.uk |accessdate=22 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090303204918/http://www.livingtv.co.uk/shows/living-with-jade-goody.php |archivedate=3 March 2009 |df=dmy-all }} In October she opened her second beauty salon, "Homme Fatel" (for men), and her second autobiography (''Jade: Catch A Falling Star'', covering her time on ''Celebrity Big Brother 5'') was published by [[John Blake Publishing]].[http://www.guardian-series.co.uk/news/4379450.LOUGHTON__Jade_Goody_s_business_partner___Success_is_the_best_tribute_/ LOUGHTON: Jade Goody's business partner: "Success is the best tribute" (From East London and West Essex Guardian Series)]{{cite news|first=Alison |last=Flood |title=John Blake buys rejected Goody |url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/58759-john-blake-buys-rejected-goody.html |publisher=The Bookseller |date=16 May 2008 |accessdate=16 May 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517111155/http://www.thebookseller.com/news/58759-john-blake-buys-rejected-goody.html |archivedate=17 May 2008 |df=dmy-all }} A documentary film, ''Jade's Cancer Battle'', was aired on 11 December{{cite news |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article5320090.ece |title=Kill It, Cook It, Eat It: Christmas Special; Jade Goody; Growing Babies: Baby Brainpower |work=The Times | location=London | first=Alex | last=Hardy | date=11 December 2008 | accessdate=5 May 2010}} with further shows planned if Goody could participate.{{cite news |url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/commissioning/interview/2008/11/jade_to_return_to_living.html |title=Jade to return to Living |work=Broadcast Now}} At the end of 2008 she played the Wicked Queen in a Christmas [[pantomime]] version of ''[[Snow White]]'' at the Theatre Royal, [[Lincoln, Lincolnshire|Lincoln]] to critical praise,{{cite news|title=Jade to play panto villain |url=http://www.thisistotalessex.co.uk/go/Jade-play-panto-villain/article-185393-detail/article.html |work=This Is Total Essex.co.uk |date=9 June 2008 |accessdate=17 June 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081226043113/http://www.thisistotalessex.co.uk/go/Jade-play-panto-villain/article-185393-detail/article.html |archivedate=26 December 2008 |df=dmy-all }} but withdrew from the production in January 2009 for health reasons.{{cite news |url=http://www.metro.co.uk/fame/article.html?Cancer_Battler_Jade_turns_to_God&in_article_id=475336&in_page_id=7 |title=Cancer Battler Jade turns to God |work=Metro}} ==Personal life== Goody had two sons.{{cn|date=December 2017}} In 2006 she began a relationship with [[Jack Tweed]], who appeared with her on ''[[Celebrity Big Brother 5 (UK)#Jack Tweed|Celebrity Big Brother]]''. In June 2007, she had a [[miscarriage]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PX3WIB187SsC&pg=PT20&dq=goody+miscarriage+2007#v=onepage&q=goody%20miscarriage%202007&f=false|title=Forever in My Heart: The Story of My Battle Against Cancer|isbn=9780007325023|author1=Goody|first1=Jade|date=2009-06-01}} After allegations of Tweed's infidelity they broke up, later reconciling. Tweed lived with Goody and her children in Buckhurst Hill, Essex, until his imprisonment{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/essex/7591786.stm |title=Jack Tweed jailed |work=BBC News | date=1 September 2008 | accessdate=26 March 2010}} for a December 2006 [[assault occasioning actual bodily harm]] on a 16-year-old boy.{{cite news|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/news/article-23548368-details/Cancer-hit+Jade+Goody+visits+boyfriend+Jack+in+prison+for+the+first+time/article.do |title=Cancer-hit Jade Goody visits boyfriend in prison for the first time |work=This is London |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090402132247/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/news/article-23548368-details/Cancer-hit%2BJade%2BGoody%2Bvisits%2Bboyfriend%2BJack%2Bin%2Bprison%2Bfor%2Bthe%2Bfirst%2Btime/article.do |archivedate= 2 April 2009 |df= }}{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/2662005/Jack-Tweed-jailed-for-18-months-for-golf-club-attack-on-boy.html |title=Jack Tweed jailed for 18 months for golf club attack on boy |date=1 September 2008 |work=The Telegraph | location=London | accessdate=5 May 2010}} He served four months of an eighteen-month sentence before his release on 27 January 2009 with [[electronic monitoring]] and a curfew.{{cite news|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/showbiz/article-23629240-details/Kisses+as+Jade+Goody+greets+her+boyfriend+outside+prison+gates/article.do |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090131044512/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/showbiz/article-23629240-details/Kisses%2Bas%2BJade%2BGoody%2Bgreets%2Bher%2Bboyfriend%2Boutside%2Bprison%2Bgates/article.do |dead-url=yes |archive-date=31 January 2009 |title=Kisses as Jade Goody Greets Her Boyfriend Outside Prison Gates |work=This is London |date=27 January 2009 |df=dmy }} Goody and Tweed exchanged rings on 15 February in a private, informal ceremony on the banks of the [[River Thames]],{{cite news |last=Moore |first=Matthew |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/4637469/Jade-Goody-exchanges-rings-with-Jack-Tweed-as-cancer-spreads.html |title=Jade Goody exchanges rings with Jack Tweed as cancer spreads |work=The Telegraph |date=17 February 2009 |accessdate=22 February 2009 | location=London}} and they married on 22 February at [[Down Hall]] country house near [[Hatfield Heath]].{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/showbiz/a147003/goody-to-wed-tweed-on-sunday.html |title=Goody to wed Tweed on Sunday |publisher=Digital Spy |date=17 February 2009 |accessdate=22 February 2009}} Goody wore a £3,500 [[Manuel Mota (fashion designer)|Manuel Mota]] dress, a gift from [[Harrods]] owner [[Mohamed Al Fayed]].{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/jade-goody/5052260/Jade-Goody-to-be-buried-in-her-wedding-dress.html |work=telegraph.co.uk |title=Jade Goody to be buried in her wedding dress |accessdate=16 April 2009 | location=London | date=26 March 2009}} The couple signed an exclusive £700,000 deal with ''OK!'' magazine for photographs of the ceremony,{{cite news |author=Ben Dowell |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/feb/18/jade-goody-wedding-deals |title=Jade Goody set to make £1m from media deals including rights to her wedding |work=The Guardian |date=18 February 2009 |accessdate=22 February 2009|location=London}} and Tweed was exempted from his curfew for 22–23 February.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7901232.stm?lss |title=Goody's fiance's curfew relaxed |work=BBC News | date=20 February 2009 | accessdate=26 March 2010}} He was convicted for [[common assault]] on 3 March 2009 for a 5 May 2008 attack on a taxi driver,{{cite news|url=http://www.thisistotalessex.co.uk/news/ONGAR-Jack-Tweed-guilty-assaulting-taxi-driver/article-741299-detail/article.html |title=Ongar:Jack Tweed found guilty of assaulting taxi driver |work=This is Total Essex |date=3 March 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090329045008/http://www.thisistotalessex.co.uk/news/ONGAR-Jack-Tweed-guilty-assaulting-taxi-driver/article-741299-detail/article.html |archivedate=29 March 2009 |df=dmy-all }} sentenced to 12 weeks' imprisonment at Harlow Magistrates Court on 14 April{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/apr/14/jade-ukcrime |work=The Guardian |title=Jack Tweed jailed for 12 weeks for taxi driver assault | location=London |date=14 April 2009}} and released on 29 May. ==Illness== Goody had a number of health scares during the 2000s. In 2002 (shortly before her ''Big Brother 3'' appearance) a [[Pap test|cervical smear test]] revealed [[Cervical squamous intraepithelial neoplasia 1|abnormal cells]], a possible indicator of cancer. She was tested for ovarian cancer in 2004 and bowel cancer in 2006, with negative results for each. Goody had hospital tests in early August 2008, after her fourth cancer scare; she had collapsed four times.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} On 19 August, while she was on the Indian reality show ''[[Bigg Boss (Indian TV series)|Bigg Boss]]'', Goody was told that test results confirmed [[cervical cancer]]. According to her spokesperson, "It looks like her cancer is at an early stage but we will have to wait until she gets back to Britain and sees a specialist and has more tests."{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} On 1 September 2008, it was reported that Goody's cancer was "advanced and life-threatening" and she would have surgery followed by [[chemotherapy]].{{cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Showbiz-News/Jade-Goody-Has-Advanced-And-Life-Threatening-Cervical-Cancer-Court-Hears/Article/200809115090929?lpos=Showbiz%2BNews_2&lid=ARTICLE_15090929_Jade%2BGoody%2BHas%2B%2527Advanced%2BAnd%2BLife-Threatening%2527%2BCervical%2BCancer%252C%2BCourt%2BHears |title=Jade's Cancer 'Life-Threatening' |work=[[Sky News]] |date=1 September 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090329021549/http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Showbiz-News/Jade-Goody-Has-Advanced-And-Life-Threatening-Cervical-Cancer-Court-Hears/Article/200809115090929?lpos=Showbiz%2BNews_2&lid=ARTICLE_15090929_Jade%2BGoody%2BHas%2B%27Advanced%2BAnd%2BLife-Threatening%27%2BCervical%2BCancer%2C%2BCourt%2BHears |archivedate=29 March 2009 |df=dmy-all }} Doctors gave her a 65-percent chance of survival.{{cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Health/Jade-Goody-Cancer-Health-celebrity-reality-star/Article/200809115092982 |title=Jade Faces Further Cancer Tests |work=[[Sky News]] |date=4 September 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090329014220/http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Health/Jade-Goody-Cancer-Health-celebrity-reality-star/Article/200809115092982 |archivedate=29 March 2009 |df=dmy-all }} Further tests and a [[radical hysterectomy]] "went well", according to her publicist, and Goody began chemotherapy and [[radiotherapy]].{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/arts/2008/0912/goodyj.html |title=RTÉ.ie Entertainment: Jade Goody has eight-hour operation |publisher=Rte.ie |date=12 September 2008 |accessdate=22 February 2009}}{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7613861.stm |title=Surgery on Jade Goody 'went well' |work=BBC News |date=13 September 2008 |accessdate=13 September 2008 }} In an interview with [[Republic of Ireland|Irish]] broadcaster [[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]], Goody said she had begun planning her funeral,{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/arts/2008/1008/goodyj.html|title=Jade Goody talks about planning funeral|publisher=RTÉ|date=8 October 2008}} was losing her hair and had decided not to explain her illness to her children, aged 4 and 5 at the time.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/arts/2008/1128/goodyj.html|title=Goody says she's losing her hair|publisher=RTÉ|date=8 October 2008}} On 4 February 2009, Goody's publicist, [[Max Clifford]], confirmed that her cancer had spread to her [[liver]], [[bowel]] and [[groin]]. A previous 40-percent chance of survival was withdrawn, and she began treatment to prolong her life. On 7 February, Clifford reported that Goody had emergency surgery in London to remove a tumour on her bowel.{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7876593.stm |title=Goody undergoes emergency surgery |work=BBC News | date=7 February 2009 |accessdate=7 February 2009 }} On 14 February, Clifford confirmed media reports that doctors at the [[Royal Marsden Hospital]] in London{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7890002.stm |title=Jade Goody 'has months to live' |work=BBC News |date=14 February 2009 |accessdate=15 February 2009}} had classified her cancer as terminal; she could die within weeks, and at best was unlikely to survive more than a few months:{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/4617493/Jade-Goody-Cancer-hit-celebrity-has-just-months-to-live.html |title=Jade Goody: Cancer-hit celebrity has just months to live |work=The Telegraph |date=14 February 2009 |accessdate=22 February 2009 | location=London}} "She was informed yesterday that tragically, she's terminally ill. She was obviously devastated."{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ukpress/article/ALeqM5jlxhKqoP09yfvTEfwS8PY9ESyXBw |title=The Press Association: Jade Goody plans to wed Jack Tweed |publisher=Google.com |date=14 February 2009 |accessdate=22 February 2009 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Goody then began drawing up a will and planning for the care of her two sons. On 5 March in the Royal Marsden Hospital, Goody asked to be [[baptism|baptised]];{{cite news|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/showbiz/article-23658031-details/%27Short+time+before+Jade%27s+suffering+ends%27/article.do |title=Short time before Jade's suffering ends |work=This is London |date=5 March 2009 |accessdate=5 March 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090306214023/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/showbiz/article-23658031-details/%27Short%2Btime%2Bbefore%2BJade%27s%2Bsuffering%2Bends%27/article.do |archivedate= 6 March 2009 |df= }} two days later, she and her sons were christened.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7930207.stm |title='Emotional' christening for Goody |work=BBC News|date=7 March 2009 |accessdate=7 March 2009}} Clifford confirmed that this was her last public appearance, and she had already said her goodbyes to her family: "We're hoping and praying that Jade pulls through, but the fact of the matter is that she now only has a short time to live." He confirmed that during the next 24 hours her doctors could assess how long Goody had to live, but she had a very short time left in any case. Jack Tweed was allowed to extend his curfew, spending a last night with his wife before she said goodbye to the rest of her family. When the news spread that Goody's cancer was terminal, medical authorities in the UK began reporting a surge in requests from women (particularly younger women) for cervical-cancer screening. This reversed a trend which had seen demand for screening decline over the past decade, with the greatest decline among women aged 25–29.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/feb/17/cancer-tests-jade-goody|title=Cancer tests go up after Jade Goody diagnosis|work=The Guardian| date=17 February 2009 |accessdate=22 February 2009 | location=London | first=James | last=Sturcke}} As a result of the publicity surrounding Goody's illness, on 13 March 2009 government health ministers agreed to review the [[National Health Service (England)|National Health Service]] policy not to screen for cervical cancer until age 25 in England (age 20 in the rest of the UK). That day, she issued a press release that she was "immensely proud" to have prompted the review.{{cite news |author=Jeremy Laurance |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-wellbeing/health-news/goody-effect-forces-ministers-to-review-cancer-screening-policy-1644903.html |title=Goody effect forces ministers to review cancer screening policy|work=The Independent |date=14 March 2009 | location=London}} ==Death== {{Wikinews|British celebrity Jade Goody dies of cervical cancer at age 27}} Goody died in her sleep in the early hours of 22 March 2009;{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/jade-goody/5031346/Jade-Goody-her-life-and-death-in-front-of-the-nation.html |title=Jade Goody – her life and death in front of the nation |work=The Telegraph |date=22 March 2009 | location=London | accessdate=5 May 2010}} her reported time of death varies by source.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/7925719.stm |title=Entertainment | Reality TV star Jade Goody dies |publisher=BBC News |date=22 March 2009 |accessdate=24 August 2012}}{{cite news |url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/UK-News/Jade-Goody-Dies-Big-Brother-Star-Has-Died-In-Her-Sleep-After-Battling-Cancer-Says-Max-Clifford/Article/200903415246579?lpos=UK_News_Carousel_Region_0&lid=ARTICLE_15246579_Jade_Goody_Dies:_Big_Brother_Star_Has_Died_In_Her_Sleep_After_Battling_Cancer,_Says_Max_Clifford |title=Big Brother Star Jade Goody Dies in Sleep |work=Sky News |date=22 March 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090325002654/http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/UK-News/Jade-Goody-Dies-Big-Brother-Star-Has-Died-In-Her-Sleep-After-Battling-Cancer-Says-Max-Clifford/Article/200903415246579?lpos=UK_News_Carousel_Region_0&lid=ARTICLE_15246579_Jade_Goody_Dies%3A_Big_Brother_Star_Has_Died_In_Her_Sleep_After_Battling_Cancer%2C_Says_Max_Clifford |archivedate=25 March 2009 |df=dmy-all }} Her mother, husband and family friend Kevin Adams were at her bedside when she passed away Goody's death was widely covered by the British media,{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/jade |title=Jade Goody | Media |publisher=The Guardian |date= 19 August 2008|accessdate=24 August 2012 |location=London}}{{cite news|last=Khan |first=Urmee |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/jade-goody/5045083/BBC-criticised-over-Jade-Goody-coverage.html |title=BBC criticised over Jade Goody coverage |publisher=Telegraph |date=25 March 2009 |accessdate=24 August 2012 |location=London}} and the BBC was criticised for its extensive coverage of her illness. The corporation later admitted on their ''[[Newswatch (UK TV series)|Newswatch]]'' programme that, upon reflection, their coverage had been excessive. [[Shilpa Shetty]], who had many confrontations with Jade when they were both on Celebrity Big Brother, visited Goody days before her death and made amends. [[Image:JadeGoody2.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Car decorated with flowers, surrounded by a large crowd|A car in Goody's funeral procession in [[The Blue]] market, Bermondsey, with ''[[East Anglia|East Angula]]'' (sic) spelt out in flowers]] Goody received tributes from all strata of society.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/mar/22/jade-goody-dies-tributes |title=Tributes pour in for Jade Goody after reality star dies from cancer, aged 27 |work=The Guardian |date=22 March 2009 | location=London | first=Matthew | last=Weaver | accessdate=26 March 2010}} British Prime Minister Gordon Brown said, "She was a courageous woman both in life and death and the whole country has admired her determination to provide a bright future for her children." Her funeral service took place at noon on 4 April at St John's [[Anglican]] Church, [[Buckhurst Hill]], Essex,[http://www.albins.co.uk/web2008/Jade.htm F. A. Albin & Sons] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090524184443/http://www.albins.co.uk/web2008/Jade.htm |date=24 May 2009 }} and later that day she was buried near her home in [[Epping Forest]].{{cite news|author=Katie Hind and Marc Baker |url=http://www.people.co.uk/news/tm_headline=her-piece-of-heaven&method=full&objectid=21217939&siteid=93463-name_page.html |title=Her Piece of Heaven |work=The People |date=22 March 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090325055913/http://www.people.co.uk/news/tm_headline%3Dher-piece-of-heaven%26method%3Dfull%26objectid%3D21217939%26siteid%3D93463-name_page.html |archivedate=25 March 2009 |df= }} The funeral cortège consisted of 21 cars, one of which was a [[Bentley]] used by the family. Several celebrities, including [[David Beckham|David]] and [[Victoria Beckham]] and [[Simon Cowell]], sent flowers, and [[Davina McCall]], [[Jamelia]] and [[Antony Costa]] were among the mourners. Goody's coffin was white; she was buried in her wedding dress with two pictures, one of each of her sons, at her side. Her sons did not attend the funeral; their father had taken them to Australia.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/jade-goody/5063869/Jade-Goodys-sons-to-miss-funeral.html |title=Jade Goody's sons to miss funeral |publisher=Telegraph |date=28 March 2009 |accessdate=10 September 2013 |location=London}} Thousands of mourners followed the funeral service on large screens outside the church. It was broadcast live on [[Sky News]], which followed the service from outside since Goody had wanted a private ceremony for friends and family.{{cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/UK-News/Jade-Goody-Funeral-Husband-Jack-Leads-Tributes-As-1000s-Gather-Outside-Church-Where-Service-Held/Article/200904115255603 |title=Thousands Say 'Goodbye' To Jade |work=Sky News |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090407040255/http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/UK-News/Jade-Goody-Funeral-Husband-Jack-Leads-Tributes-As-1000s-Gather-Outside-Church-Where-Service-Held/Article/200904115255603 |archivedate=7 April 2009 |df=dmy-all }} ==Legacy== ===Tributes=== Sky Living aired five tributes to Goody, documenting her early life, fame and final months, from 2009 to 2012. The final episode of ''Big Brother'' on [[Channel 4]] featured a 15-minute tribute, praising her as the ultimate ''Big Brother'' contestant. '''Jennifer Gilbert''' (born December 24, 1968) is an American [[entrepreneur]] and [[TV personality]]. She is the founder and chief visionary officer of ''Save the Date'', a [[New York City|New York]]–based special events company. She was named one of the ''entrepreneurs of the year'' by [[Ernst & Young]] for her event planning company, ''Save the Date'' in 1998.<ref>{{cite web|title=Enchanted Evenings: New York's Top Event Planners|author=Polster, Allison|url=https://gotham-magazine.com/new-yorks-top-event-planners|website=[[Gotham (magazine)|gotham-magazine.com]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref> She has also appeared on the TV series ''[[Real Housewives of New York City]]''.<ref>{{cite web|author=Ernst, Amanda|title=Jennifer Gilbert Reacts To Her Hilarious ‘Real Housewives’ Debut|url=http://www.crushable.com/2010/05/07/entertainment/exclusive-jennifer-gilbert-reacts-to-her-hilarious-real-housewives-debut/|date=May 7, 2010|website=crushable.com|publisher=[[Defy Media]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref name="ref1">{{cite news|author=Palmer, Amy|title=When a 20-Year-Old Secret is Revealed: 'I Refuse to Be A Victim'|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/amy-palmer/jennifer-gilbert_b_1519270.html|date=May 7, 2010|work=[[HuffPost]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author1=Cruz, Clarissa|author2=Bailly, Jenny|url=http://www.oprah.com/style/female-authors-model-summer-fashion-under-100|title=7 Authors Model Summer's Most Sizzling (Under-$100!) Outfits|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref>
==Early life and career== Gilbert graduated from the [[University of Vermont]] in 1990 and received a [[Bachelor of Science]] in [[Consumer market|Consumer Marketing]] with a minor in Business. After graduation Gilbert moved to [[New York City]]. In 1991, at the age of 22, a stranger attacked her, stabbing her 37 times with a screwdriver before leaving her for dead.<ref name="ref1"/><ref>{{cite web|title=The Scars You Don't See|url=http://www.marieclaire.com/world-reports/jennifer-gilbert-attack|website=[[Marie Claire|marieclaire.com]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jennifer-gilbert/finally-an-anniversary-to_b_10228850.html|title=Finally, an Anniversary to Celebrate|author=Gilbert, Jennifer|date=June 2, 2016|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Abbasi, Jennifer|url=https://www.success.com/article/jennifer-gilbert-woman-warrior|title=Jennifer Gilbert: Woman Warrior|date=April 11, 2014|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref>
After recovering, she decided to become an [[Event planning|event planner]] and started ''Save the Date'', a New York based [[event planning]] company, in 1994.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.inc.com/magazine/201207/burt-helm/jennifer-gilbert-save-the-date-how-i-did-it.html|title='Why I Will Never Be a Victim'|date=June 28, 2012|magazine=[[Inc. (magazine)|Inc.]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=How I Rebuilt My Life After Being Attacked|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/jennifer-gilbert/how-i-rebuilt-my-life-after-attack_b_1581340.html|author=Gilbert, Jennifer|date=August 6, 2012|work=HuffPost|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref> In 2010 she sued a dating company with similar name called Save the Dating, the company went off business after lawsuit.<ref>{{cite news|author=Cowles, Charlotte|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2010/04/new_housewife_jennifer_gilbert.html|title=New Housewife Jennifer Gilbert Sues New York Matchmaking Business; Gerunds Involved|work=[[New York Post]]|date=April 9, 2010|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref> The company has rendered services to many notable companies including several in [[Fortune 500]] companies and has been retained by clients such as [[Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation]], [[Oprah Winfrey]] and singer [[Jewel (singer)|Jewel]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Jennifer Gilbert - Who is She|url=http://www.ladieswholaunch.com/magazine/jennifer-gilbert/1094|publisher=ladieswholaunch.com|date=May 11, 2004|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.entrepreneur.com/video/277455|title=Jennifer Gilbert Bounced Back From a Near-Fatal Attack to Find Massive Business Success|author=Schultz, Erin|website=Entrepreneur|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref>
She is also the co-owner of Portamee, a [[baby carrier]] company.<ref>{{cite web|title=Portamee - who are WEe|url=http://www.portamee.com/who.html|publisher=portamee.com|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref> She has also authored a book, ''I Never Promised You A Goodie Bag'', in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=I Never Promised You a Goodie Bag: A Memoir of a Life Through Events--the Ones You Plan and the Ones You Don't|url=https://www.amazon.com/Never-Promised-You-Goodie-Events/dp/B00B558OSO|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Jennifer Gilbert, Author Of Memoir 'I Never Promised You A Goodie Bag,' Talks Success After Violence|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/05/14/jennifer-gilbert-i-never-promised-you-a-goodie-bag_n_1516243.html|work=HuffPost|accessdate=April 26, 2018|date=May 14, 2012}}</ref> In her book, she discussed about how her life changed after being attacked at a young age and then how she got control on her life and started a successful company.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jennifer Gilbert|url=http://www.myfoxny.com/story/18441551/jennifer-gilbert|date=May 17, 2012|publisher=myfoxny.com|accessdate=May 19, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120819012819/http://www.myfoxny.com/story/18441551/jennifer-gilbert |archivedate=August 19, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> She spoke at [[TEDx]] [[Barnard College|Barnard College Women]] sharing her entrepreneurial spirit and philosophy.<ref>{{cite web|title=Entrepreneurial Spirit: Jennifer Gilbert at TEDxBarnardCollegeWomen|url=http://socksonanoctopus.com/ted-talks-entrepreneurial-spirit-jennifer-gilbert/|publisher=Soccks on an Octopus|accessdate=April 26, 2018}}</ref>
==TV appearances== She appeared as herself in the [[Bravo (U.S. TV channel)|Bravo's]] hit TV series ''[[Real Housewives of New York City]]'' in 2010.<ref>{{cite news|title=New 'Housewife' Jennifer Gilbert Loses Airtime, Cut From Reunion Special|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/06/03/new-housewife-jennifer-gi_0_n_598857.html|author=Rancilio, Alicia|agency=[[Associated Press|AP]]|date=February 6, 2010|work=[[HuffPost]]|accessdate=May 19, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129085209/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/06/03/new-housewife-jennifer-gi_0_n_598857.html|archivedate=November 29, 2014|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> She was the party planner for [[Jill Zarin]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Meet NYC’s new ‘Real Housewives’ set to shake up the show|url=https://nypost.com/2010/04/01/meet-nycs-new-real-housewives-set-to-shake-up-the-show/|date=April 1, 2010|publisher=[[nypost.com]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018|author=Eber, Hailey}}</ref>
==Personal life== In 1994, Gilbert met her husband, a [[Wall Street]] Executive, Bennett Egeth and the two were married in [[New York City]] 7 years later.
Gilbert lives in [[New York City]] with her husband, their daughter and twin boys.<ref>{{cite news|title=WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS: VOWS; Jennifer Gilbert and Bennett Egeth|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/12/01/style/weddings-celebrations-vows-jennifer-gilbert-and-bennett-egeth.html|date=December 1, 2002|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|accessdate=April 26, 2018|author=Louie, Elaine}}</ref>
