border-style: solid;border-color:black;"|  |- | height=6| |} ==Final== The final of Melodifestivalen 2010 was held on 13 March 2010 at the [[Ericsson Globe|Globe Arena]] in [[Stockholm]]. 10 songs qualified for the final, two from each of the four semi-finals and the ''Andra Chansen'' round. The winner was decided by a mix of televoting/SMS voting and jury voting. The running order for the final had been revealed on 7 March 2010. [[Darin Zanyar|Darin]] opened the final with his song "[[You're Out of My Life (Darin song)|You're Out of My Life]]", and [[Eric Saade]] closed the performances with "[[Manboy]]".{{cite web|url=http://esctoday.com/news/read/15323|title=Running order for Melodifestivalen final announced|last=Hondal|first=Victor|date=2010-03-07|publisher=''ESCToday''|accessdate=7 March 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100308220658/http://esctoday.com/news/read/15323|archivedate=8 March 2010|df=}} Before the start of rehearsals [[Anna Bergendahl]] became the favourite to win the final with her song "[[This Is My Life (Anna Bergendahl song)|This Is My Life]]", leading with all Swedish bookmakers over [[Salem Al Fakir]] and [[Timoteij]]. However many international fans put [[Timoteij]] as their favourite to win the contest with "[[Kom (Timoteij song)|Kom]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=7671 |title=All bookmakers agree; Anna Bergendahl to win Melodifestivalen |date=2010-03-10 |publisher=''Oikotimes'' |accessdate=10 March 2010 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The interval act for the final was a Norwegian "invasion", and a medley of Melodifestivalen and Eurovision songs from Norway and Sweden. Acts performing in the interval act included [[Afro-dite]], [[Charmed (group)|Charmed]], [[Shirley Clamp]], [[Maria Haukaas Storeng]], [[Marie Rosenmir]], [[One More Time (band)|One More Time]], [[Lars-Ante Kuhmunen]], [[Roger Pontare]], Åge Sten "Glam" Nilsen of [[Wig Wam]], Jakob Samuel of [[The Poodles]], [[Towa Carson]], [[Hanne Krogh]], [[Kikki Danielsson]], [[Bobbysocks!]], [[Chips (band)|Chips]], and [[Kikki, Bettan & Lotta]], concluding with Norway's [[Eurovision Song Contest 2009]] winner [[Alexander Rybak]].{{cite web|url=http://esctoday.com/news/read/15369|title=Norway invades Swedish final|last=Poglajen|first=Primoz|date=2010-03-12|publisher=''ESCToday''|accessdate=12 March 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100314214115/http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/15369|archivedate=14 March 2010|df=}} A rock version of last year's Melodifestivalen winner "[[La voix]]" was also performed by the band [[Casablanca (band)|Casablanca]], joined by last year's winner [[Malena Ernman]].{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/15378|title=Sweden has rehearsed for the big night|last=Repo|first=Juha|date=2010-03-13|publisher=''ESCToday''|accessdate=13 March 2010}} [[Anna Bergendahl]] was the winner of Melodifestivalen 2010 with "[[This Is My Life (Anna Bergendahl song)|This Is My Life]]", coming first in the public televote and second in the jury vote. The jury favourite, [[Salem Al Fakir]], finished in 2nd place.{{cite web|title=Hela resultatlistan|url=http://svt.se/2.121594/1.1926380/svt_hela_resultatlistan?lid=senasteNytt_1793492&lpos=rubrik_1926380|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=30 October 2010|language=Swedish|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100603041926/http://svt.se/2.121594/1.1926380/svt_hela_resultatlistan?lid=senasteNytt_1793492&lpos=rubrik_1926380|archivedate=3 June 2010|df=}} 3,870,000 people viewed the final show on SVT.{{cite web|title=Veckorapport 10-2010|url=http://www.mms.se/_dokument/rapporter/vecka/VeTvTitt1010.pdf|publisher=Mediamätning i Skandinavien|accessdate=30 October 2010|language=Swedish}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !rowspan="2"|Draw !rowspan="2"|Artist !rowspan="2"|Song

{{Infobox event |title = Murder of Margaret Martin |image = Margaret Martin.PNG |caption = Margaret Martin |date = December 17–20, 1938 |place = Luzerne County, Pennsylvania/Wyoming County, Pennsylvania, United States |type = [[Homicide]] |reported deaths = 1 (victim) |burial = St. Ignatius Church in Kingston |coroner = R. W. Greenwood<ref name = "pottstownmercury"/> |convicted = No conviction (unsolved case) }}
'''Margaret Martin''' (1918/19 – December 1938) was a resident of [[Kingston, Pennsylvania]], United States, who went missing on December 17, 1938, and was found dead in [[Wyoming County, Pennsylvania]], several days later.<ref name = "citizensvoice"/> Martin was a recent graduate of the [[Wilkes-Barre Business College]]. On December 17, 1938, she met an unknown man who claimed to be offering her a secretarial job, and was never seen alive again. Her body was discovered in the wilderness {{convert|25|mi|km}} away by a hunter four days later. Martin's death resulted in a lengthy manhunt. Numerous suspects were examined, but no one was ever convicted of the crime. As of {{currentyear}}, it remains an unsolved case and it is unlikely that the perpetrator will ever be discovered.
==Victim== Margaret Martin was a resident of Kingston, in [[Luzerne County, Pennsylvania]].<ref name = "citizensvoice"/> She graduated from [[Kingston High School (Pennsylvania)|Kingston High School]] in 1937.<ref name = "timesleader"/> She took classes at the [[Wilkes-Barre Business College]] to gain secretarial skills and graduated with honors at the beginning of December 1938.<ref name = "pottstownmercury"/><ref name = "timesleader"/> She was 19 years old at the time of her death.<ref name = "citizensvoice">{{Citation|author = Erin L. Nissley|newspaper = [[The Citizens' Voice]]|url = http://citizensvoice.com/news/kingston-resident-s-1938-slaying-remains-unsolved-1.1619195|title = Kingston resident's 1938 slaying remains unsolved|date = January 19, 2014|accessdate = September 9, 2015}}</ref>
According to Betty Hopkins, a former classmate, Martin was "a shy, studious, friendly girl who had many friends".<ref name = "timesleader">{{Citation|author = Joe Healy|newspaper = [[Times Leader]]|url = http://archives.timesleader.com/1999/1999_02/1999_01_24_A_GRUESOME_MURDER_THAT_WENT_UNSOLVED_WHO_KILLED_YOUNG_MARGARET_M.html|title = A gruesome murder that went unsolved: who killed young Margaret Martin?|date = January 24, 1999|accessdate = September 9, 2015}}</ref> Her parents described her as "a living saint".<ref name = "pottstownmercury"/> She was also a devout Catholic.<ref name = "pottstownmercury2">{{Citation|newspaper = [[Pottstown Mercury]]|url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3188770//|title = Sandy-Haired Man is Sought|page = 3|date = December 23, 1938|accessdate = September 9, 2015|via = [[newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref>
Martin's father was John Martin, a local foreman and minor politician.<ref name = "pottstownmercury"/> Margaret Martin was the eldest of four children.<ref name = "bristoldailycourrier">{{Citation|newspaper = [[The Bristol Daily Courrier]]|url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3189928//|title = Blame Sex Pervert for the Murder of 19-Year-Old Girl|page = 4|date = December 22, 1938|accessdate = September 9, 2015|via = [[newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref>
==Disappearance== On December 17, 1938, a man contacted Martin, claiming that he was setting up an insurance company and needed a [[secretary]],<ref name = "timesleader"/> adding that he had heard of her through the Wilkes-Barre Business College.<ref name = "chicagotribune">{{Citation|newspaper = [[Chicago Tribune]]|url = http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1938/12/23/page/4/article/mother-and-victim|title = Mother and Victim|date = December 23, 1938|accessdate = September 9, 2015}}</ref> The two agreed to meet in Kingston Corners, not far from Martin's home.<ref name = "timesleader"/>
Martin was first noted to be missing that evening, after she had failed to return home from the alleged job interview.<ref name = "citizensvoice"/><ref name = "timesleader"/> Several witnesses said they had seen her getting into a brown Plymouth or black [[sedan (automobile)|sedan]] with a man after a brief conversation.<ref name = "citizensvoice"/><ref name = "pottstownmercury2"/><ref name = "timesmirror">{{Citation|newspaper = [[Warren Times Mirror]]|url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3189812//|title = Inquest Being Held Today in Brutal Murder|page = 9|date = December 28, 1938|accessdate = September 9, 2015|via = [[newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> This was the last time she was seen alive.<ref name = "citizensvoice"/><ref name = "timesleader"/><ref name = "pottstownmercury2"/> The witnesses were able to give only vague descriptions of the man, described as a "suave, neat, sandy-haired young man", and did not identify the car's license plate.<ref name = "pottstownmercury"/><ref name = "citizensvoice"/> The man was between 25 and 30 years of age and slightly overweight.<ref name = "pottstownmercury2"/> Martin's friends and family called the police and started a search, but her disappearance was difficult to publicize since the local newspapers were on strike.<ref name = "timesleader"/>
==Death and discovery of the body== According to a 1999 article in the ''[[Times Leader]]'', Martin was tortured and murdered in a sawmill in the mountains about {{convert|15|mi|km}} from the creek where her body was found.<ref name = "timesleader"/> According to theories by the police, the killer had attempted to dismember her body and destroy it in the mill's [[firebox (architecture)|firebox]], but had been scared off by the mill's owner, James Kedd. Kedd had assumed that the killer was a mere trespasser and had fired a warning shot in the killer's direction.<ref name = "timesleader"/> The killer then drove to a point close to the creek and carried Martin's body the final 75 yards to the creek, where he abandoned it.<ref name = "bristoldailycourrier"/>
Initially, it was suspected that Martin's disappearance was linked to a [[sex slavery]] ring.<ref name = "pottstownmercury"/> However, her body was discovered in the forested wilderness of [[Northmoreland Township, Wyoming County, Pennsylvania|Northmoreland Township, Wyoming County]], on December 21, 1938, about {{convert|25|mi|km}} from her home.<ref name = "timesleader"/><ref name = "chicagotribune"/><ref name = "gettysburgtimes">{{Citation|agency = [[Associated Press]]|newspaper = [[The Gettysburg Times]]|url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3188480//|title = Find Shreds of Martin Clothes|date = December 29, 1938|accessdate = September 9, 2015|via = [[newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> The discoverer was 19-year-old Anthony Rezykowski, who was trapping [[muskrat]]s in the area.<ref name = "citizensvoice"/><ref name = "timesleader"/> Rezykowski noticed a large burlap bag partially submerged in {{convert|2|ft|m}} of water in a creek.<ref name = "bristoldailycourrier"/> Upon further investigation, he found the bag to contain the mutilated body of a young woman with no clothing. The body was soon identified as Margaret Martin's.<ref name = "citizensvoice"/> At the time of her body's discovery, she had been dead for at least 24 hours. If not for Rezykowski's discovery of her body, it may have gone unnoticed for several years.<ref name = "bristoldailycourrier"/>
Martin's body showed signs of having been beaten{{mdash}}perhaps with a rock{{mdash}}and strangled.<ref name = "citizensvoice"/> She had bruises on her throat and body, as well as knife wounds on her stomach and thigh.<ref name = "pottstownmercury"/><ref name = "timesleader"/> Her [[autopsy]] found the cause of death to be strangulation and stated that she had "suffered the molestation of a degenerate".<ref name = "pottstownmercury"/><ref name = "citizensvoice"/>
==Initial investigations== [[File:Investigators at the scene of the discovery of Margaret Martin's body.PNG|thumb|left|Investigators at the location where Martin's body was discovered]] After the discovery of Martin's body, approximately 75 state troopers combed the area in search of clues.<ref name = "pottstownmercury2"/> However, no tire tracks were seen near the site where her body was found, and the burlap bag proved to be of no use in identifying any suspects. According to ''[[The Citizens' Voice]]'', burned cloth matching the clothing Martin was wearing when she was last seen was discovered at an abandoned sawmill near [[Forkston, Pennsylvania|Forkston]].<ref name = "citizensvoice"/> However, an article in ''[[The Kane Republican]]'' stated that this was not the origin of the cloth.<ref name = "kanerepublican"/> An incident involving a bundle of clothing being thrown from a car near [[Orwigsburg, Pennsylvania|Orwigsburg]] proved to be unrelated to Martin's killing.<ref name = "gettysburgtimes"/>
On December 22, the ''[[Scranton Tribune]]'' predicted that Martin's killer would be arrested within 24 hours.<ref name = "pottstownmercury">{{Citation|newspaper = [[Pottstown Mercury]]|url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3188592//|title = Mad Killer's Description Spurs Police Hunt for Girl's Slayer|page = 1|date = December 23, 1938|accessdate = September 9, 2015|via = [[newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref>
Many hundreds of people attended Martin's funeral at St. Ignatius Church in Kingston on December 24.<ref name = "timesleader"/> Plainclothes police officers also attended her funeral in the hopes of noticing anyone suspicious attending.<ref name = "citizensvoice"/><ref name = "timesleader"/>
Several theories about the identity of Martin's murderer were suggested by locals. These included a [[mortician]] from Wyoming County, a businessman's son who left the area soon after the murder, a local assistant pastor, a teacher at the Wilkes-Barre Business College, and a local teenager who had a crush on Martin.<ref name = "timesleader"/> Two men who had attempted to attack a 16-year-old girl from [[Hanover Township, Luzerne County, Pennsylvania|Hanover Township, Luzerne County]], were also investigated.<ref name = "gettysburgtimes"/> Some investigators believed that due to the killer's familiarity with the area's terrain, the killer must have been a local. More recently, it has been suggested that the killer was actually a non-local [[serial killer]].<ref name = "timesleader"/>
==Impact and aftermath== On December 28, 1938, Pennsylvania state senator [[Leo C. Mundy]] stated that at the next state legislature, he would introduce a bill making sex crimes punishable by execution and requiring registration for all sex offenders. Mundy had resolved to introduce the bill due to Martin's murder. Physicians and welfare and social service workers would also be required to report anyone with tendencies towards such offenses.<ref name = "timesmirror"/>
By the beginning of 1939, most clues pertaining to Martin's murder had proven to be useless.<ref name = "kanerepublican">{{Citation|newspaper = [[The Kane Republican]]|url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3189979//|title = Clews In Martin Murder Case Have About Vanished|page = 1|date = January 3, 1939|accessdate = September 9, 2015|via = [[newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}}</ref> The manhunt for the killer was still ongoing in February of that year, but the police had not turned up any more information.<ref>{{Citation|newspaper = [[The Indiana Gazette]]|url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3190060//|title = Two-Month Manhunt Leaves Police Blank as to Killer of Martin Girl|page = 2|date = February 15, 1939|accessdate = September 9, 2015}}</ref> In June 1939, further clues were discovered, but the killer was not identified.<ref>{{Citation|newspaper = The Morning Herald|url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3190099//|title = New Clues Found In Martin Death|page = 8|date = June 23, 1939|accessdate = September 9, 2015|via = [[newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref>
Although a very large number of suspects were investigated after Martin's death, no perpetrator was ever identified.<ref name = "citizensvoice"/><ref>{{Citation|newspaper = [[The Bristol Daily Courier]]|url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3190191//|title = The Capitol Whirl|date = September 17, 1954|accessdate = September 9, 2015|via = [[newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref>
In September 1942, Orban Taylor of [[New York City]] confessed to Martin's murder. However, his confession was proven to be [[false confession|false]] after ten hours of investigation.<ref name = "harrisburg">{{Citation|newspaper = [[Harrisburg Sunday Courier]]|url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3190156//|title = Police Probe 4-Year Murder|page = 1|date = September 20, 1942|accessdate = September 9, 2015|via = [[newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> Taylor was not charged with that crime although he did confess to several other crimes.<ref name = "citizensvoice"/><ref name = "harrisburg"/>
In 1948, a decade after Martin's murder, the case was one of the few major unsolved murders in Pennsylvania.<ref>{{Citation|newspaper = [[Pittston Gazette]]|url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3190167//|title = Martin Girl Slain Ten Years Ago|page = 3|date = December 17, 1948|accessdate = September 9, 2015|via = [[newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> In 1999, Peter Paul Olszewski, Jr., who was at the time the Luzerne County District Attorney, stated that even with modern criminal investigation methods and forensic techniques, it is unlikely that the identity of Martin's killer will be discovered. It is presumed that the killer is now long-deceased.<ref name = "timesleader"/>

{{For|other uses of the term|Novosti (disambiguation){{!}}Novosti}} {{Infobox magazine | title = Novosti | logo = Novosti logo.png | image_file = Novosti Magazine cover June 3 2013.jpg | logo_size = | editor = [[Nikola Bajto]] | editor_title = [[Editor-in-chief]] | previous_editor = | staff_writer = | frequency = Weekly | circulation = 8,000 | category = [[Politics]], [[Current affairs (news format)|current affairs]] ([[Left-wing politics|Left wing]]<ref name="RWB">{{cite web|url=https://rsf.org/en/news/croatian-nationalists-want-serbian-minority-newspaper-close|title=Croatian nationalists want Serbian minority newspaper to close|publisher=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|accessdate=5 April 2017}}</ref>) | publisher = [[Serb National Council]] | firstdate = December 1999 | country = [[Croatia]] | based = [[Zagreb]] | language = [[Croatian language|Croatian]], [[Serbian language|Serbian]] | website = {{URL|www.portalnovosti.com}} | issn = 1845-8955 }}
'''''Novosti''''' ({{lang-sr-Cyrl|Новости}}, lit. ''The News'') is a [[Croatia]]n weekly magazine based in [[Zagreb]]. It is published by the [[Serb National Council]] (SNV), the main state-funded body concerned with promotion of human rights and dealing with issues of ethnic identity and participation of Serbs in Croatia.<ref name="SNVonama">{{cite web|url=http://www.snv.hr/about-snv/|title=About SNV|publisher=Serb National Council|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> The organization was established in July 1997 in Zagreb, based on the provisions granting the right to self-government for Serbs in Croatia as set in the [[Erdut Agreement]].<ref name="SNVonama"/>
The magazine, billed as an "independent Serb weekly" (''samostalni srpski tjednik''), describes its editorial policy as being primarily concerned with covering general news and publishing "critical writing about all the relevant political, social and cultural developments in Croatia". It also deals with issues related to the Serb community in Croatia and the development of [[civil society]].<ref name="novostionama"/>
The ''Novosti'' weekly was originally launched by SNV in December 1999 in [[broadsheet]] format as a weekly publication primarily concerned with [[minority politics]] related to [[Serbs of Croatia]].<ref name="novostionama">{{cite web|url=http://www.novossti.com/o-novostima/|title=O Novostima|work=Novosti|language=Croatian|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> Since its first issue the magazine adopted a policy of linguistic pluralism and featured articles written in both [[Croatian language|Croatian]] and [[Serbian language|Serbian]] varieties of [[Serbo-Croatian]], and offered a mix of sections printed in Latin and [[Cyrillic]] scripts.<ref name="monitor">{{cite web|url=http://www.monitor.hr/clanci/srpski-tjednik-novosti-od-pocetka-prosinca-na-kioscima/26482/|title=Srpski tjednik Novosti od početka prosinca na kioscima|date=17 November 2009|work=Internet Monitor|language=Croatian|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> However, its circulation was limited to subscribers and was not widely available in [[newsstands]] for the first ten years of its existence.<ref name="index">{{cite web|url=http://www.index.hr/vijesti/clanak/srpski-tjednik-novosti-od-prosinca-na-kioscima-/460509.aspx|title=Srpske "Novosti" od prosinca u slobodnoj prodaji na hrvatskim kioscima|date=17 November 2009|work=[[Index.hr]]|language=Croatian|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
In late 2009 the magazine underwent an extensive makeover in an effort to transform it into a weekly magazine which would also appeal to the mainstream public, with more space dedicated to commentary pieces and coverage of nationally significant political and cultural events, as well as [[investigative journalism]].<ref name="monitor"/> To that extent, the magazine hired a number of prominent columnists and intellectuals as commentators, including [[Viktor Ivančić]] (formerly of ''[[Feral Tribune]]''), [[Boris Dežulović]], [[Vladimir Arsenijević]], [[Tomislav Jakić]] and [[Igor Mandić]], and was for the first time made available for purchase at newsstands.<ref name="monitor"/>
As of December 2009 its circulation is 8,000.<ref name="index"/> Its editor-in-chief is [[Ivica Đikić]], formerly of ''[[Novi list]]'' daily. Over the time magazine published interviews with [[Noam Chomsky]],<ref name="Intervju1">{{cite web|url=http://www.portalnovosti.com/noam-chomsky-trump-je-zastrasujuca-figura|title=Noam Chomsky: Trump je zastrašujuća figura|date=3 October 2016|work=Novosti|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> [[Etgar Keret]],<ref name="Intervju2">{{cite web|url=http://www.portalnovosti.com/etgar-keret-nacionalisti-utjehu-traze-na-krivim-mjestima|title=Etgar Keret: Nacionalisti utjehu traže na krivim mjestima|date=19 December 2016|work=Novosti|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> [[Zygmunt Bauman]],<ref name="Intervju3">{{cite web|url=http://www.portalnovosti.com/zygmunt-bauman-velika-avantura-zvana-evropa-jos-nije-okoncana|title=Zygmunt Bauman: Velika avantura zvana ‘Evropa’ još nije okončana|date=22 November 2016|work=Novosti|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> [[Henry Giroux]],<ref name="Intervju4">{{cite web|url=http://www.portalnovosti.com/henry-giroux-amerika-klizi-u-neofasizam|title=Henry Giroux: Amerika klizi u neofašizam|date=20 November 2016|work=Novosti|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> [[Srećko Horvat]],<ref name="Intervju5">{{cite web|url=http://www.portalnovosti.com/srecko-horvat-nudimo-europski-nju-dil|title=Srećko Horvat: Nudimo europski New deal|date=23 August 2016|work=Novosti|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> [[Milorad Pupovac]],<ref name="Intervju6">{{cite web|url=http://www.portalnovosti.com/milorad-pupovac-potezi-predsjednice-su-nedopustivi-i-sramni|title=Milorad Pupovac: Potezi predsjednice su nedopustivi i sramni|date=9 December 2016|work=Novosti|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> [[Chris Hedges]],<ref name="Intervju7">{{cite web|url=http://www.portalnovosti.com/chris-hedges-trump-je-morbidni-simbol-amerike|title=Chris Hedges: Trump je morbidni simbol Amerike|date=4 July 2016|work=Novosti|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> [[Jacques Rancière]],<ref name="Intervju8">{{cite web|url=http://www.portalnovosti.com/jacques-ranciere-ne-postoji-kljuc-za-buducnost|title=Jacques Rancière: Ne postoji ključ za budućnost|date=29 January 2016|work=Novosti|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> [[Vivek Chibber]],<ref name="Intervju9">{{cite web|url=http://www.portalnovosti.com/vivek-chibber-sto-znaci-imati-pravu-burzoaziju|title=Vivek Chibber Što znači ‘imati pravu buržoaziju’?|date=17 June 2015|work=Novosti|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> [[Filip David]],<ref name="Intervju10">{{cite web|url=http://www.portalnovosti.com/filip-david-zlo-ima-bezbroj-lica|title=Filip David Zlo ima bezbroj lica|date=17 February 2015|work=Novosti|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> [[Georges Wolinski]],<ref name="Intervju11">{{cite web|url=http://www.portalnovosti.com/georges-wolinski-najbolji-ljevicari-su-satiricari|title=Georges Wolinski Najbolji ljevičari su satiričari|date=7 January 2015|work=Novosti|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> [[Mladen Ivanić]],<ref name="Intervju12">{{cite web|url=http://www.portalnovosti.com/mladen-ivanic-mijenjat-cu-medjunarodni-imidz-republike-srpske-i-bih|title=Mladen Ivanić Mijenjat ću međunarodni imidž Republike Srpske i BiH|date=1 December 2014|work=Novosti|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> [[Vesna Teršelič]],<ref name="Intervju13">{{cite web|url=http://www.portalnovosti.com/vesna-terselic-obespravljene-su-civilne-zrtve-rata-a-ne-branitelji|title=Vesna Teršelič Obespravljene su civilne žrtve rata, a ne branitelji|date=10 November 2014|work=Novosti|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> [[Andrej Nikolaidis]],<ref name="Intervju14">{{cite web|url=http://www.portalnovosti.com/andrej-nikolaidis-padne-li-syriza-dolazi-zlatna-zora|title=Andrej Nikolaidis Padne li Syriza, dolazi Zlatna zora|date=7 February 2015|work=Novosti|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> and [[Mirjana Karanović]].<ref name="Intervju15">{{cite web|url=http://www.portalnovosti.com/mirjana-karanovic-ovaj-kusturica-nije-onaj-kojeg-sam-poznavala|title=Mirjana Karanović: Ovaj Kusturica nije onaj kojeg sam poznavala|date=12 November 2016|work=Novosti|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref>
==Criticism==
[[Political satire]] and [[social commentary]] are integral part of Novosti editorial policy. This at some points caused strong criticism among some [[Croatian nationalism|Croatian nationalists]] with dogmatic views on historical events such as [[Croatian War of Independence]], who saw ridicule of [[militarism]], [[Croatian military]] and national symbols as unacceptable excess of limits of [[freedom of speech]].<ref name="Večernji1">{{cite web|url=http://www.vecernji.hr/hrvatska/udruga-vigilare-napala-novosti-zbog-obrade-hrvatske-himne-1019574|title=Udruga Vigilare napala Novosti zbog obrade hrvatske himne|publisher=Večernji list|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref><ref name="N1">{{cite web|url=http://hr.n1info.com/a134755/Vijesti/Od-Hrvatskog-radija-3-do-Hrvatskog-krugovala-3.html|title=Od Hrvatskog radija 3 do Hrvatskog krugovala 3|publisher=N1 TV|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref><ref name="DW">{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/hr/uzroci-i-posljedice-kape-sa-slovom-u/a-19056213|title=Uzroci i posljedice kape sa slovom "U"|publisher=DW|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> Some of them were calling for cancellation of funding the newspapers from public money, criminal prosecution or [[censorship]].<ref name="Večernji2">{{cite web|url=http://www.vecernji.hr/hrvatska/hsp-podnio-kaznenu-prijavu-protiv-snv-a-tjednika-novosti-i-milorada-pupovca-1019141|title=HSP podnio kaznenu prijavu protiv SNV-a, tjednika Novosti i Milorada Pupovca|publisher=Večernji list|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> Some [[mainstream]] politicians in Croatia, including the president [[Kolinda Grabar-Kitarović]], warned the editors that they shall take care what they are writing about implicitly calling them to use [[self-censorship]].<ref name="Predsjednica">{{cite web|url=http://net.hr/danas/hrvatska/odgovor-na-dramaticno-pupovcevo-pismo-predsjednica-osudila-govor-mrznje-ali-i-napala-novosti-bivseg-premijera/|title=ODGOVOR NA PISMO: Predsjednica osudila govor mržnje, ali i napala Novosti, bivšeg premijera…|publisher=net.hr|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref><ref name="autofraf">{{cite web|url=http://www.autograf.hr/nikola-bajto-ja-pjevam-o-haubici-i-domoljubni-sam-pjesnik/|title=Nikola Bajto: "Ja pjevam o haubici i domoljubni sam pjesnik"|publisher=autograf.hr|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> President stated that she consider journal satire to be inappropriate and similar to cartoons of [[Muhammad]] in foreign press such as [[Charlie Hebdo]].<ref name="Predsjednica"/><ref name="Peščanik">{{cite web|url=http://pescanik.net/zemlja-nelagode/|title=Zemlja nelagode|publisher=Peščanik|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> On April 4, 2017 [[Reporters Without Borders]] condemned ''"a campaign of lawsuits and verbal attacks that Croatian nationalist groups have been orchestrating for several months against Novosti, the newspaper of Croatia’s Serbian minority"''.<ref name="RWB"/> Some of the sentences published in Novosti that made part of the Croatian public feel insulted, were following:
''"Asshole Croatia is a national state of assholes and their public service"''<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vecernji.hr/premium/budite-junaci-pa-stanite-iza-supacke-hrvatske-1152598|title=Budite junaci pa stanite iza 'Šupačke Hrvatske'|access-date=2017-09-06|language=hr}}</ref>
''"Scientists brag that they found the reason for existence of an [[Appendix (anatomy)|appendix]], while for Croatian sovereignty, up to this day, no one knows what it serves for, or does it even exists...".''<ref name="ws_admin">{{Cite news|url=https://potpisi.me/peticija/zaustavimo-financiranje-vrije%C4%91anja-hrvata-i-republike-hrvatske-iz-na%C5%A1ih-d%C5%BEepova|title=Zaustavimo financiranje vrijeđanja Hrvata i Republike Hrvatske iz naših džepova!|last=ws_admin|date=2017-02-20|work=Potpisi.me|access-date=2017-09-06|language=hr}}</ref>
Initiators of the petition for repeal of the funding refer to the same tender criterium which enabled the funding of Novosti weekly, which states: "''those who promote intolerance towards any national minority or majority, will be banned from contesting on [this] tender in period of 3 years''"<ref name="ws_admin"/>

{{Infobox operational plan | name = Operation Quartz | partof = the [[Rhodesian Bush War]] | image = [[File:Rhodesian_Eland902.jpg|300px]] | caption = [[Eland 90|Eland-90 armoured cars]] of the [[Rhodesian Armoured Corps]] | scope = | type = [[Decapitation strike]] | location = | coordinates = | map_type = | latitude = | longitude = | map_size = | map_caption = | map_label = | planned = | planned_by = | commanded_by = [[Peter Walls]] | objective = Assassination of [[ZANU-PF]] leadership, destruction of [[ZANLA]] | target = | date = {{Start date|1980|02|14|df=y}} | time = | time-begin = | time-end = | timezone = | executed_by = | outcome = Cancelled | casualties = | fatalities = | injuries = }} {{Campaignbox Rhodesian Bush War}}
'''Operation Quartz''' was a planned [[military operation]] to be conducted by the [[Rhodesian Security Forces|Rhodesian armed forces]] against [[Robert Mugabe]] and [[ZANU-PF]] in the event that party lost the [[Southern Rhodesian general election, 1980]]. The operation was organized on the assumption ZANU-PF would attempt to violently seize the government should it lose the election. ZANU-PF ultimately won the election and Operation Quartz was never executed.
==Planning== [[File:President Zimbabwe , Robert Mugabe bezoekt Nederland Robert Mugabe , kop, Bestanddeelnr 932-1922.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Robert Mugabe, pictured here in 1982, was one of the targets of Operation Quartz.]] Operation Quartz had two elements. The first involved strikes against armed units of the [[Zimbabwe African National Liberation Army]] (ZANLA, ZANU-PF's military wing) that had concentrated at 11 assembly points prior to the election, to be carried out by Rhodesian infantry and armour units supported by the Rhodesian Air Force. The second element called for the simultaneous assassinations of Robert Mugabe, [[Rex Nhongo]], and [[Simon Muzenda]] by the [[Rhodesian SAS]].<ref name="walls"/>
In addition to the Rhodesian Army and Rhodesian Air Force, it is believed that the South African Armed Forces may have planned a supporting role in Operation Quartz.<ref name="walls"/>
Some accounts of Operation Quartz have inaccurately described it as a planned [[military coup]] against the extant government of [[Abel Muzorewa]] to prevent it from handing over power to Mugabe, alleging [[Peter Walls]] called off the operation three hours before [[H-Hour]]. The allegations may have originated in dubious information leaked by the British government.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Moorcraft|first1=Paul|title=The Rhodesian War: A Military History|publisher=Stackpole Books|isbn=0811707253|page=178|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oL-jaeM63P8C&dq=%22}}</ref>
==Aftermath== The ZANU-PF won a majority of votes in the election and Operation Quartz was never executed.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Licklider|first1=Roy|title=New Armies from Old: Merging Competing Military Forces After Civil Wars|date=2014|publisher=Georgetown University Press|isbn=1626160430|page=66|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wGGgAwAAQBAJ&source=gbs_navlinks_s}}</ref> Following the ZANU-PF victory, details of Operation Quartz came to light and Walls, who had initially been retained by Mugabe as head of the armed forces, was accused in parliament of [[treason]]. On the advice of members of the government, Walls left the country for his own safety.<ref name="walls">{{cite book|last1=Baxter|first1=Peter|title=Bush War Rhodesia 1966–1980|date=2014|publisher=Hellion & Co.|isbn=1909982377|pages=59–63|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=x0iuCAAAQBAJ&dq=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Preston|first1=Matthew|title=Ending Civil War: Rhodesia and Lebanon in Perspective|date=2004|publisher=I.B. Tauris|isbn=9781850435792|pages=194–195}}</ref>

{{Handel operas}} '''''Riccardo primo, re d'Inghilterra''''' ("Richard the First, King of England", [[HWV]] 23) is an [[opera seria]] in three acts written by [[George Frideric Handel]] for the [[Royal Academy of Music (1719)]] . The Italian-language [[libretto]] was by [[Paolo Antonio Rolli]], after [[Francesco Briani]]'s ''Isacio tiranno'', set by [[Antonio Lotti]] in 1710. Handel wrote the work for the Royal Academy's 1726–27 opera season, and also as homage to the newly crowned [[George II of Great Britain|George II]] and the nation where Handel had just received citizenship.Dean, Winton, "Handel's ''Riccardo Primo''" (July 1964). ''[[The Musical Times]]'', '''105''' (1457): pp. 498–500. ''Riccardo Primo'' was the third opera Handel composed for the trio of famous star Italian singers, the castrato [[Senesino]] and the sopranos [[Francesca Cuzzoni]] and [[Faustina Bordoni]]. ==Performance history== [[File:King George II by Charles Jervas.jpg|thumb|George II in his coronation robes]] The opera received its premiere at the [[Her Majesty's Theatre|King's Theatre]] in London on 11 November 1727, and 11 subsequent performances. It was also performed in Hamburg and Braunschweig in February 1729.Händel, ''Riccardo primo, Re d'Inghilterra''. ed. Andreas Köhs. piano reduction. Bärenreiter 2007, Kassel p. X The Hamburg performance, led by none other than [[Georg Philipp Telemann]], included two new comic characters, Murmilla and Gelasius; [[recitative]]s and the added [[aria]]s for the new characters were translated into German although the original arias remained in Italian. Handel subsequently re-used music from the opera in ''[[Scipione]]'' and ''[[Tolomeo]]''. The opera fell into neglect after the 1728 closing of the Royal Academy. ''Riccardo Primo'' was rediscovered and performed by the [[Handel Opera Society]] at [[Sadler's Wells Opera]] in London on 8 July 1964.Dean, Winton, "Handel Operas" (September 1964). ''The Musical Times'', '''105''' (1459): pp. 670–671. Later performances were given at [[Kourion]] Amphitheater in Cyprus at 1991, in order to mark the 800th anniversary of the historical events on which the opera is based, at the 1996 [[Göttingen International Handel Festival|Göttingen Festival]]Drakeford, Richard, "Festival Reviews: Virtue & Pleasure" (September 1996). ''The Musical Times'', '''137''' (1843): pp. 36+38. and at the Händelfestspiele at the Badisches Staatstheater in 2014 and 2015. The work was given its United States premiere, presented as ''Richard the Lionheart'', by [[Opera Theatre of Saint Louis]] during the summer 2015 season.Sarah Bryan Miller, [http://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/arts-and-theatre/culture-club/opera-theatre-announces-season/article_ab75d5a8-9005-52ee-ad2c-2dc19fbd28d4.html "Opera Theatre announces 2015 season"], on stltoday.com. Retrieved 28 February 2015 ==Roles== {| class="wikitable" !Role{{cite web|title=List of Handel's Works |url=http://gfhandel.org/1to42.html |website=Gfhandel.org |publisher=Handel Institute |accessdate=28 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714173520/http://gfhandel.org/1to42.html |archivedate=July 14, 2014 }} ![[Voice type]] !Premiere cast, 11 November 1727 |- | Riccardo | [[alto]] [[castrato]] | Francesco Bernardi,called "[[Senesino]]" |- | Costanza, ''daughter of the King of Navarre'' | [[soprano]] | [[Francesca Cuzzoni]] |- | Isacio, ''Governor of Cyprus'' | [[bass (voice type)|bass]] | [[Giuseppe Maria Boschi]] |- | Pulcheria, ''his daughter'' | soprano | [[Faustina Bordoni]] |- | Oronte, ''Prince of Syria'' | alto castrato | Antonio Baldi |- | Berardo, ''Costanza's cousin'' | bass | [[Giovanni Battista Palmerini]] |} ==Synopsis== :Time: 1191 :Place: Cyprus The story concerns the marriage of [[Richard I of England]] to Constanza, a [[Spain|Spanish]] princess. The character of Costanza is identified with [[Berengaria of Navarre]], who married Richard I at [[Limassol]] at 1191. [Prior to the action of the opera, Riccardo and Costanza have not yet met.] ===Act 1=== ''Cyprus'' On her sea journey to be married to Riccardo, Costanza and her party are shipwrecked off the coast of Cyprus. She finds shelter at the court of the local governor, Isacio, pretending that she and her tutor, Berardo, are actually brother and sister, Doride and Narsete, servants of Costanza. Oronte (engaged to Pulcheria) is attracted to 'Doride'. Pulcheria overhears him paying court and is angry. Riccardo arrives, disguised as his kingdom's ambassador, and asks after Costanza. Isacio guesses "Doride's" real identity and promises to give up Costanza to Riccardo. ===Act 2=== [[File:Merry-Joseph Blondel - Richard I the Lionheart.jpg|left|thumb| Richard I the Lionheart]] Isacio, knowing that Riccardo has never seen his fiancée, proposes to send his daughter Pulcheria to Riccardo in her stead, leaving the way open for his seduction of Costanza, whom he forces to admit her real identity. Pulcheria agrees, out of duty to her father, but intends to reveal the deception at the right moment. Oronte has discovered Isacio's plot through Berardo and stops it at the moment that Riccardo and Pulcheria meet for the first time, which leads Pulcheria to forgive her fiancé. Riccardo is angry upon learning of Isacio's designs and proposes to overthrow the tyrant in alliance with Oronte. He retains his disguise and plans to offer charity towards Isacio in spite of the ill plotting. Speaking "on behalf" of Riccardo, "the Ambassador" offers Isacio the choice of either peace or war. Pulcheria pleads for Costanza and Isacio agrees to bestow her on Riccardo. Pulcheria introduces Riccardo, initially as the 'ambassador, but then revealed as his true self, to Costanza, and act 2 closes with a love duet for Costanza and Riccardo. ===Act 3=== Riccardo tells Oronte how Isacio has gone back on his word and launched an attack against Riccardo at the moment that he was about to leave with Costanza. Despite the help of Oronte's forces, Costanza is taken back by Isacio. Pulcheria, seeing the captive Costnza's distress, offers herself as a hostage to Riccardo's forces. Isacio offers his prisoner his hand in marriage and his throne. Berardo intervenes to announce the renewed approach of the English army. Isacio is defiant. As Riccardo bursts into the palace, Isacio threatens to kill Costanza. As Riccardo is about to concede, Pulcheria seizes a sword and announces she will kill herself if Costanza is harmed. In the following confusion Oronte enters and his superior forces prompt Isacio to flee. The women are left alone to hope for a just victory for Riccardo and Oronte returns to announce that the English king has been victorious. Riccardo dispenses justice as follows. Isacio must renounce his power, but is allowed to live. Pulcheria, with Oronte as her husband, shall reign in place of her father.{{cite web|title=Riccardo Primo|url=https://handelhendrix.org/learn/about-handel/opera-synopses/riccardo-primo/|website=handelhendrix.org|accessdate=29 December 2016}} ==Context and analysis== [[File:London Kings Theatre Haymarket.jpg|thumb|The King's Theatre, London, where ''Riccardo Primo'' had its first performance]] The German-born Handel, after spending some of his early career composing operas and other pieces in Italy, settled in London, where in 1711 he had introduced Italian opera for the first time with his opera ''[[Rinaldo (opera)|Rinaldo]]''. A tremendous success, ''Rinaldo'' created a craze in London for Italian opera seria, a form focused overwhelmingly on solo arias for the star virtuoso singers. In 1719, Handel was appointed [[Kapellmeister|music director]] of an organisation called the Royal Academy of Music (unconnected with the present-day London conservatoire), a company under royal charter to produce Italian operas in London. Handel was not only to compose operas for the company but hire the star singers, supervise the orchestra and musicians, and adapt operas from Italy for London performance.Dean, W. & J.M. Knapp (1995) ''Handel's operas 1704–1726,'' p. 298.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1qw8AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA273 |title=Essays on Handel and Italian opera by Reinhard Strohm |via=[[Google Books]] |date= |accessdate=2013-02-02}} Handel had composed numerous Italian operas for the Academy, with varying degrees of success; some were enormously popular. The castrato Senesino and the soprano Francesca Cuzzoni had appeared in a succession of Handel operas for the Academy (he was not the only composer who composed operas for the company) most of which had been successful with audiences, and in 1726 the directors of the Academy brought over another internationally renowned singer, [[Faustina Bordoni]], to add to the company's attractions. The two [[prima donna]]s had appeared in continental European countries in operas together without incident, but in London they developed rival groups of fans who interrupted the performances with rowdy displays of partisanship for one lady or another. This came to a climax on 6 June 1727 during a performance at the King's Theatre of ''Astianatte'' by [[Giovanni Bononcini]] with both singers onstage and royalty in the audience. Fist fights and disorder between rival groups of fans broke out in the audience and the two sopranos exchanged insults and came to blows onstage. The rest of the opera was cut, the performers going straight to the short final chorus. The scandal was gleefully repeated in the newspapers, in satirical skits on other stages, and in mock-heroic verse, bringing the entire form of Italian opera into a certain amount of disrepute in London. Handel had to supply another opera for the trio of star singers, Senesino, Cuzzoni and Faustina (as she was known) even though these singers received astronomical fees, much more than he received for composing the works.{{cite book|last1=Snowman|first1=Daniel|title=The Gilded Stage: A Social History of Opera|date=2010|publisher=Atlantic Books|isbn=978-1-84354-466-1}} Combined with declining audience numbers caused at least in part by the ridicule brought upon Italian opera by the rival sopranos' public spat, these factors were causing severe financial difficulty for the Royal Academy of Music. As one of Handel's most loyal supporters, [[Mary Delaney]], wrote in 1727:
I doubt operas will not survive longer than this winter, they are now at their last gasp; the subscription is expired and nobody will renew it. The directors are all squabbling, and they have so many divisions among themselves that I wonder they have not broke up before. Senesino goes away next winter, and I believe Faustina, so you see harmony is almost out of fashion.{{cite book|last1=Burrows|first1=Donald|title=Handel (Master Musicians)|date=2012|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-973736-9}}
The Royal Academy of Music collapsed at the end of the 1728–29 season, partly due to the huge fees paid to the star singers, and Cuzzoni and Faustina both left London for engagements in continental Europe. Handel started a new opera company with a new prima donna, [[Anna Strada]]. One of Handel's librettists, [[Paolo Antonio Rolli|Paolo Rolli]], wrote in a letter (the original is in Italian) that Handel said that Strada "sings better than the two who have left us, because one of them (Faustina) never pleased him at all and he would like to forget the other (Cuzzoni)."{{cite web|title=Lotario|url=https://handelhendrix.org/learn/about-handel/opera-synopses/lotario/|website=handelhendrix.org|accessdate=29 December 2016}} The opera was not revived by Handel, although to 18th century musicologist [[Charles Burney]] it contained much fine music, including an aria for Faustina, ''Vado per obedirti'', which:
is the most agreeable song of execution of the times. I have been told that the brilliancy of her voice made its way through the busy accompaniment of this song in a manner which filled the whole theatre. A close in this air appears for the first time, which has since become fashionable, as well as the return to the subject in the Da Capo.Charles Burney: ''A General History of Music: from the Earliest Ages to the Present Period.'' Vol. 4. London 1789, reprint: Cambridge University Press 2010, {{ISBN|978-1-108-01642-1}}, p. 327.
R.B. Chatwin has discussed Handel's writing of orchestral parts for the [[chalumeau]], a forerunner of the [[clarinet]], as part of the [[Musicology|musicological]] controversy over whether or not Handel wrote music for the clarinet or its precursors.Chatwin, R.B., "Handel and the Clarinet" (March 1950). ''The [[Galpin Society]] Journal'', '''3''': pp. 3–8. [[Winton Dean]] and [[Richard Drakeford]] have commented on the weaknesses of the dramatic characterisations in the libretto. The opera is scored for recorder, flute, bass flute or two chalumeaux, two oboes, bassoon, three trumpets, two horns, timpani, strings and [[Figured bass|continuo]] (cello, lute, harpsichord). ==Recordings== {| class="wikitable" !Year !Cast:

{{EngvarB|date=July 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Refimprove|date=August 2013}} The '''National Day Rally''' ([[Simplified Chinese|Chinese]]: 国庆群众大会, {{lang-ms|Rapat Umum Hari Kebangsaan}}) is an annual address that the [[Prime Minister of Singapore]] makes to the entire nation, on the first or second Sunday after [[National Day (Singapore)|National Day]] on 9 August.{{cite news |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/from-babies-to-casinos-10-memorable-national-day-rally-speeches |title=From babies to casinos: 11 memorable National Day Rally speeches |last=Chew |first=Hui Min |date=20 August 2016 |work=[[The Straits Times]]}} A yearly event since 1966, the Prime Minister uses the rally to address the nation on its key challenges and announce major policy changes, and is comparable to the [[State of the Union]] address delivered by the [[President of the United States]].{{cite news |url=http://mothership.sg/2016/08/pm-lee-mentions-pokemon-in-his-national-day-rally-trailer/ |first=Martino |last=Tan |title=PM Lee mentions "Pokémon" in his National Day rally trailer |date=20 August 2016 |work=[[Mothership.sg]]}} ==History== The rally began in 1966 as a "private meeting" between the Prime Minister and community leaders. The transcript was released to the media only two weeks later. Only in 1971 did [[Lee Kuan Yew]] decide "at the last minute" to televise the speech, which has since been annually broadcast live. The first rally in 1966 was held on the eve of National Day. Since 1967, the rally has been held at least a week after National Day. The rally was delivered at the former [[Singapore National Theatre|National Theatre]] from 1966 to 1983. With the theatre's closure and demolishment in 1984, the rally was held at the [[Singapore Conference Hall]] for two years before being shifted to [[Kallang Theatre]] from 1986 to 2000. In 2001, the rally moved to the University Cultural Centre at the [[National University of Singapore]]. Since 2013, [[Lee Hsien Loong]] has held his rally at the [[ITE College Central|ITE Headquarters and ITE College Central]].{{cite web | url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/pm-lee-to-deliver/724994.html | title=PM Lee to deliver National Day Rally speech at ITE Headquarters and College Central | work = [[Channel NewsAsia]] | publisher = [[Mediacorp]] | accessdate=26 June 2013}} ===1966 National Day Rally=== The first National Day Rally was held on 8 August 1966 at the [[Singapore National Theatre|National Theatre]]. A closed-door meeting, Lee Kuan Yew told community leaders, "Every year, on this 9th August for many years ahead - how many, I do not know - we will dedicate ourselves anew to consolidate ourselves to survive; and, most important of all, to find an enduring future for what we have built and what our forebears will build up." ===1971 National Day Rally=== The 1971 rally was the first to be televised, at Lee Kuan Yew's "last minute" decision. Since then, the rally has become "a fixture on the political calendar". Lee delivered his "cautiously optimistic" speech "off the cuff", remarking, "You have done well - six superb years, a magnificent performance against all the odds, so much so that everybody says, 'But, of course, everybody knows that Singapore is a very well-endowed place...Oh, just natural course of events.' It wasn't, you know. We made it so..." ===1981 National Day Rally=== The 1981 rally marked the first time where [[Cabinet of Singapore|Cabinet]] ministers delivered their speeches.{{cite news | url=http://www.nas.gov.sg/archivesonline/audiovisual_records/record-details/483c0dcb-1164-11e3-83d5-0050568939ad | title=National Day Rally - Speeches By Dr Tony Tan, Lim Chee Onn, Goh Chok Tong And Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew}} ===1983 National Day Rally=== At the 1983 rally, Lee Kuan Yew "trotted out facts and figures to show that the more highly educated a woman was, the less likely she was to reproduce", before concluding, "[W]e are really discarding our able parents in the next generation and doubling the less able." The resulting controversy eroded electoral support for his [[People's Action Party]] for several years. ===1988 National Day Rally=== In 1988, Lee Kuan Yew delivered "one of his most quoted lines": "And even from my sick bed, even if you are going to lower me into the grave, and I feel that something is going wrong, I'll get up." ===1991 National Day Rally=== In 1991, [[Goh Chok Tong]] delivered his maiden speech at the National Day Rally. He "spoke with a self-deprecating humour that heralded a new, gentler style of governance", which he underscored by remarking, "I am not going to follow [Lee Kuan Yew's] act. I am going to walk my own way." ===2002 National Day Rally=== At the 2002 rally, Goh Chok Tong remarked, "Fair-weather Singaporeans will run away whenever the country runs into stormy weather. I call them 'quitters'. Fortunately, 'quitters' are in the minority. The majority of Singaporeans are 'stayers'...As we say in Hokkien, 'pah see buay zao'." His labels generated "much discussion". ===2004 National Day Rally=== In 2004, [[Lee Hsien Loong]] made his maiden address at the National Day Rally. However, rather than deliver a "cautious speech", he "surprised many by slaughtering a few sacred cows". He promoted a new "teach less, learn more" education policy, introduced a shortened five-day work week for the [[Singapore Civil Service|Civil Service]], and, most controversially, mooted the idea of casinos in Singapore. In 1970, Lee Kuan Yew's response to casinos in Singapore had been "no, not over my dead body", though the elder Lee had since changed his mind.{{cite news |url=http://www.asiaone.com/singapore/his-decades-parliament |date=27 March 2015 |title=His decades in Parliament |work=[[The New Paper]]}} ===2005 National Day Rally=== In 2005, [[Lee Hsien Loong]] adopted the current format of delivering his Malay and Chinese remarks at 6:45 pm, with a break at 7:30 pm, before commencing his English address at 8:00pm. Prior to 2005, the rally was a continuous speech from 8:00pm.{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} ===2007 National Day Rally=== In 2007, opposition and [[Nominated Members of Parliament]] were invited to the National Day Rally for the first time.{{cite news |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/politics/opposition-parties-hold-outreach-events |title=Opposition parties hold outreach events |date=24 August 2015 |last=Chong |first=Zi Liang |work=[[The Straits Times]] |location=[[Singapore]]}} ===2008 National Day Rally=== In 2008, the English language telecast of the rally, initially scheduled for live broadcast at 8pm on 17 August, was postponed to the next day. The move was to allow Singaporeans to watch Singapore take on [[China]] in the women's table tennis finals at the [[2008 Summer Olympics|Beijing Olympics]]. The rally itself proceeded as usual at the University Cultural Centre, but was only broadcast the next day.{{cite news | title = Broadcast of National Day Rally English speech postponed to Monday | work = [[Channel NewsAsia]] | publisher = [[Mediacorp]] | date = 16 August 2007 | url = http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/368702/1/.html }} ===2009 National Day Rally=== In 2009, Singaporeans used the [[Twitter]] hashtag #ndrsg to tweet about the rally. ===2010 National Day Rally=== The 2010 rally was held on the last Sunday of August to avoid clashing with the [[2010 Summer Youth Olympics|Youth Olympic Games]] earlier that month. ===2012 National Day Rally=== The 2012 rally marked the second time where [[Cabinet of Singapore|Cabinet]] ministers delivered their speeches at 6.45pm, before the Prime Minister's remarks at 8pm. It was also the first to feature sign-language translation in real time. It was held on the last Sunday of August to facilitate [[Hari Raya|Ramadan]] festivities. ===2013 National Day Rally=== The 2013 rally was the first to be held at the [[ITE College Central|ITE Headquarters and ITE College Central]] after nine years at the [[National University of Singapore]]'s University Cultural Centre. Lee said the move was "for a serious purpose - to underscore my longstanding commitment to investing in…every Singaporean".{{cite web |url=http://www.pmo.gov.sg/newsroom/prime-minister-lee-hsien-loongs-national-day-rally-2013-english |title=Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's National Day Rally 2013 (English) |website=[[Prime Minister's Office (Singapore)|Prime Minister's Office]]}} ===2015 National Day Rally=== In his 2015 speech, "set within the context of...[[Singaporean general election, 2015|an impending general election]]", [[Lee Hsien Loong]] "asked for a strong mandate" without being "baldly partisan". Lee also mentioned two ministers, [[Vivian Balakrishnan]] and [[Lim Swee Say]], who would respectively be standing in [[Holland-Bukit Timah GRC]] and [[East Coast GRC]], the two most contested [[People's Action Party|PAP]]-held constituencies.{{cite web |url=https://www.ipscommons.sg/the-politics-of-the-ndr-2015-speech/ |first=Gillian |last=Koh |date=24 August 2015 |website=[[Institute of Policy Studies (Singapore)|Institute of Policy Studies]] |title=[The Angle] The Politics of the NDR 2015 Speech}} === 2016 National Day Rally === An hour and 20 minutes into his English remarks at the 2016 rally, Lee Hsien Loong suddenly took ill at 9.20pm. Half an hour later, [[Deputy Prime Minister of Singapore|Deputy Prime Minister]] [[Teo Chee Hean]] announced that Lee would resume his speech. The [[Prime Minister's Office (Singapore)|Prime Minister's Office]] also said that Lee had felt "unsteady because of prolonged standing, heat and dehydration", adding, "His heart is fine and he did not have a stroke." At 10.40pm, he returned to speak for another 15 minutes. By then, he looked well and thanked the audience for waiting for him, who gave him a standing ovation.{{Cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/politics/anxiety-then-relief-as-pm-completes-rally-after-taking-ill|title=Anxiety, then relief, as PM Lee Hsien Loong completes rally after taking ill|last=hermes|date=2016-08-21|access-date=2016-08-22}} ===2017 National Day Rally=== The 2017 rally was held on 20 August 2017 at ITE College Central. Lee's speech mainly focused on the obstacles which Singapore was currently facing, namely [[Diabetes]], [[Pre-school]] and [[Technology]]. {{cite web|url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/national-day-rally-2017-six-key-takeaways-9140632|title=National Day Rally 2017: Six key takeaways|publisher=}} ===2018 National Day Rally=== The 2018 rally was held at the ITE College Central on 19 August 2018,{{cite web|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/politics/national-day-rally-2018-to-be-held-on-aug-19|title=National Day Rally 2018 to be held on Aug 19|first=|last=hermesauto|date=19 March 2018|publisher=}} with the rally focused on trending issues such as housing, healthcare and cost of living. Lee introduced, among other policies, the Merdeka Generation Package (a spin-off from the [[Pioneer Generation Package]]), the Voluntary Early Redevelopment Scheme and a revamped Home Improvement Programme. He also announced that Singapore would be seeking a second inscription on [[UNESCO]]'s World Heritage List of [[hawker centre#In Singapore|her hawker culture]], and that Senior Minister of State and Mayor [[Maliki Osman]] would be leading an improvement project for [[Geylang Serai]].{{cite web|url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/pm-lee-national-day-rally-ndr-2018-things-you-need-to-know-10631096|title=National Day Rally 2018: The 8 things you need to know|publisher=}} ==Format== ===Broadcast=== The programme used to be aired as a single slot programme from 8 pm onwards. Since 2005, the rally is usually broadcast live from 6.45pm till 10pm (SST), with a break between 7.30pm and 8pm (the break was extended to 8.15 pm from 2017 onwards), across [[MediaCorp]] channels.{{cite news|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/specialreport/news/367942_74/1/.html|title=MediaCorp to broadcast PM Lee's Nat'l Day Rally Speech "live" Sunday|accessdate=14 August 2008 | work = [[Channel NewsAsia]] | publisher = [[Mediacorp]]}} However, most English rallies were over-run and most programmes on MediaCorp had postponed to the following week but some programmes were shown immediately after the English rally. [https://www.pmo.gov.sg/national-day-rally-2018 English] |} ==Response== {{Copypaste|section|date=July 2017}} An article titled "Singapore's National Day Rally Speech: A Site of Ideological Negotiation"{{cite journal | last = Tan | first = Kenneth Paul | title = Singapore's National Day Rally speech: A site of ideological negotiation | journal = [[Journal of Contemporary Asia]] | volume = 37 | issue = 3 | pages = 292–308 | publisher = [[Taylor and Francis]] | doi = 10.1080/00472330701408635 | date = August 2007 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/00472330701408635 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} Also available [http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Singapore's+National+Day+Rally+speech:+a+site+of+ideological...-a0168089152 online.] analyses the inaugural National Day Rally speeches of three Singapore prime ministers. It locates these speeches in the continuous ideological work that the People's Action Party (PAP) government has to do to maintain consensus and forge new alliances among classes and social forces that are being transformed by globalisation. Increasingly, these speeches have had to deal with the contradictions between nation-building and the tensions between the liberal and reactionary tendencies of the global city. According to Kenneth Paul Tan of the Lee Kuan Yew school of Public Policy: "The rally speech has also been a part of larger celebrations surrounding the commemoration of Singapore's independence gained on 9th August 1965. These celebrations have come to include a short and formal televised National Day message from the Prime Minister, observance ceremonies held at organizations in the public and private sectors, constituency dinners and ministerial speeches, regularly televised music videos of patriotic songs composed for the celebrations, and - most spectacular of all - a National Day parade that since the mid-1980s has included not only a traditional ceremonial segment , but also high-tech mass performances and re-enactments of the official "Singapore Story" that end on a climax of fireworks (Kong and Yeoh, 1997).{{cite journal |last1=Kong|first1=Lily|last2=Yeoh|first2=Brenda S.A. | title = The construction of national identity through the production of ritual and spectacle | journal = [[Political Geography (journal)|Political Geography]] | volume = 16 | issue = 3 | pages = 213–239 | publisher = [[Elsevier]] | doi = 10.1016/0962-6298(95)00135-2 | date = March 1997 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0962-6298(95)00135-2 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} Clearly the symbolic and formal aspects of the speech are just as important as its contents, taking Singaporeans collectively to an emotional high. This is especially so during general election years, when the prime minister announces the PAP's "report card" of achievements in government as well as the distribution of election "goodies" to the Singaporean masses - the lower income voters in particular - as a way of reinforcing the image of government as benevolent provider." "As an annual injection of patriotism, the National Day celebrations help to inoculate Singaporeans against the disenchantment that accompanies advanced industrial societies, whether they are formally classified as capitalist or socialist, democratic or authoritarian. Singaporeans are reminded every year of the PAP's pioneer leaders - Lee Kuan yew and his "lieutenants" (Lam and Tan,1999){{cite book|editor-last1=Er|editor-first1=Lam Peng|editor-last2=Tan|editor-first2=Kevin Yl|title=Lee's lieutenants: Singapore's old guard|date=2000|publisher=Allen & Unwin|location=St. Leonards, NSW.|isbn=9781864486391}} - who have been written into the official "Singapore Story" as the brave and far-sighted founders of contemporary Singapore (Loh,1998).{{cite journal |last=Loh|first=Kah Seng | title = ‘No more road to walk’: cultures of heritage and leprosariums in Singapore and Malaysia | journal = International Journal of Heritage Studies | volume = 17 | issue = 3 | pages = 230–244 | publisher = [[Taylor and Francis]] | doi = 10.1080/13527258.2011.556660 | date = May 2011 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/13527258.2011.556660 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} Both volumes of Lee's own memoirs - tellingly titled ''the Singapore Story'' - have become central texts of the Singapore Story, supplemented by glossy publications such as the National Heritage Boards (1998) ''Singapore: Journey Into nationhood'' as well as other educational and information materials" "The PAP knows that its authority will be secure as long as it remains able to make Singaporeans believe that it can continue to deliver material prosperity and security for all, regardless of race. Therefore, the PAP has had to reassert its relevance constantly by insisting on Singapore's fundamentally vulnerable nature and condition, an insistence that has sustained a culture of fear and arrested the risky global environment, the PAP also knows that the transactional basis on which its authority is built has become fragile and therefore needs to be strengthened by moral authority, what Burns (1978){{cite book|last1=Burns|first1=James MacGregor | title = Leadership |date=2010|publisher=HarperPerennial|location=New York|isbn=9780061965579|edition=1st |series = Harper Perennial Political Classics Series}} has identified as a transformative mode of leadership, through which it can uplift, inspire and motivate in times of real crisis." ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.pmo.gov.sg Prime Minister's Office website] - Official website of the Singapore Prime Minister's Office. * [http://www.reach.gov.sg REACH's website] - The Singapore government's official website for public consultation and feedback. * [http://www.ndr.sg Mobile Webcast site] - Mobile webcast of the event. * [http://www.channelnewsasia.com/rally Channel NewsAsia microsite] - MediaCorp's live webcast site. * [http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/national-day-rally-word-cloud TODAY online Newspaper] - Interactive Graphic. {{Infobox aircraft occurrence | occurrence_type = Accident | name = Sknyliv air show disaster | image = Sukhoi Su-27 (Su-27S), Ukraine - Air Force AN1185525.jpg | caption = A [[Sukhoi Su-27]] performing at an air show | date = {{start date|df=y|2002|07|27}} | type = [[Pilot error]] | site = [[Sknyliv|Sknyliv Airfield]]
near [[Lviv]], [[Ukraine]] | aircraft_type = [[Sukhoi Su-27]] | tail_number = | operator = [[Ukrainian Air Force]]
([[Ukrainian Falcons]]) | crew = 2 – Volodymyr Toponar and co-pilot Yuriy Yegorov (ejected to safety) | injuries = 543 (on ground)
2 (in aircraft) | fatalities = 77 (on ground) }} [[File:Lviv Airlines Ilyushin Il-76MD Shevelev-1.jpg|thumb|The damaged IL-76MD]] The '''Sknyliv air show disaster''' occurred on 27 July 2002, when a [[Ukrainian Air Force]] [[Sukhoi Su-27]] piloted by Volodymyr Toponar and co-piloted by Yuriy Yegorov crashed during an [[aerobatics]] presentation at [[Sknyliv|Sknyliv airfield]] near [[Lviv]], [[Ukraine]]. The accident killed 77 people and injured 543, 100 of whom were hospitalised. {{As of|2002|alt=}}, it was [[Lists of air show accidents and incidents|the deadliest air show accident in history]]. == Accident == More than 10,000 spectators attended the Saturday [[air show]], staged to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the [[Ukrainian Air Force]]'s 14th Air Corps.{{Cite web|url=http://dlib.eastview.com/browse/doc/13715639|title=EVXpress – Deadly Performance. Ukrainian Militarys Prestige Crashes on Lvov Airfield – The Current Digest of the Russian Press, 2002, No. 30, Vol. 54|website=dlib.eastview.com|access-date=2016-12-16}} The Su-27 aircraft was flown by two experienced pilots; it entered a rolling maneuver at 12:52 p.m. with a downward trajectory at low altitude. It rolled upright once more and was still descending rapidly when the left wing dropped shortly before it hit the ground, at which point the crew initiated ejection. The aircraft flattened out initially, skidding over the ground towards stationary aircraft and striking a glancing blow against the nose of an [[Ilyushin Il-76]] transport aircraft before beginning to explode and cartwheel into the crowd of spectators. Both pilots survived with minor injuries, while 77 spectators were killed, including 28 children{{cite news|last1=Kozyrieva|first1=Tetiana|title=Two Sknyliv boys seven years later|url=http://www.day.kiev.ua/en/article/society/two-sknyliv-boys-seven-years-later|access-date=27 June 2015|work=[[The Day (newspaper)|The Day]]|date=8 September 2009}} (though initial reports by the Emergency Situations Ministry put the number of dead at 83, including 23 children).{{Cite news|last=Horodetska|first=Olena|url=https://www.questia.com/read/1G1-89911650/pilots-blamed-for-world-s-worst-air-show-disaster|title=Pilots Blamed for World's Worst Air Show Disaster|date=30 July 2002|newspaper=[[Birmingham Post]]|access-date=23 May 2015|subscription=yes|via=[[Questia Online Library]]}} Another 100 were hospitalized for head injuries, burns, and bone fractures.{{cite journal | title = Deadly Performance. Ukrainian Militarys Prestige Crashes on Lvov Airfield | journal = The Current Digest of the Russian Press | date = August 21, 2002 | first = Svetlana | last = Stepanenko | volume = 54 | issue = 30 | pages = 16| id = | url = http://dlib.eastview.com/browse/doc/13715639 | access-date = 2011-03-24 | quote = Debris from the exploding SU-27 sprayed across the field for a distance of about 100 meters. As of yesterday, 83 people (19 of them children) were dead, and more than 100 were taken to the hospital with head injuries, burns and fractures.}}{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/2159332.stm | work=BBC News | title=Pilots blamed for Ukraine air disaster | date=29 July 2002}} Other injuries were less severe and did not require hospitalization; a total of 543 people were injured during the accident.{{cite journal | title = Pilots Convicted for Disaster During Air Show | journal = The Current Digest of the Russian Press | date = July 27, 2005 | first = Roman | last = Kirillov | volume = 56 | issue = 26 | pages = 9–10 | id = | url = http://dlib.eastview.com/browse/doc/13772846 | access-date = 2011-03-24 | quote = While performing an aerobatic maneuver, an SU-27 jet crashed into a crowd of spectators, leaving 77 people dead and another 543 injured. The commander of the plane's crew, Vladimir Toponar, was sentenced Friday to 14 years in prison, and copilot Yury Yegorov got eight years | deadurl = bot: unknown | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fdlib.eastview.com%2Fbrowse%2Fdoc%2F13772846&date=2011-03-24 | archivedate = March 24, 2011 | df = }} Following the disaster, the pilots stated that the flight map which they had received differed from the actual layout. On the [[Flight recorder#Cockpit voice recorder|cockpit voice recorder]], one pilot asks, "And where are our spectators?"{{Cite web|url=http://dlib.eastview.com/browse/doc/13716213|title=EVXpress – Ukrainian Pilots Failed to Obey Female Voice – The Current Digest of the Russian Press, 2002, No. 31, Vol. 54|website=dlib.eastview.com|access-date=2016-12-16}} Others have suggested that the pilots were slow to react to automated warnings issued by the flight computer. == Aftermath == Ukrainian President [[Leonid Kuchma]] publicly blamed the military for the disaster and dismissed head of the air force, General Viktor Strelnykov.http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/not_in_website/syndication/monitoring/media_reports/2160690.stm Defense minister [[Volodymyr Shkidchenko]] sent in his resignation, but Kuchma rejected it.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/2178539.stm | work=BBC News | title=Ukraine crash report blames pilots | date=7 August 2002}} On 24 June 2005, a military court sentenced pilot Volodymyr Toponar and co-pilot Yuriy Yegorov to 14 and 8 years in prison, respectively. The court found the two pilots and three other military officials guilty of failing to follow orders, negligence, and violating flight rules. Two of the three officials were sentenced to up to six years in prison, and the last official received up to four years. In addition, Toponar was ordered to pay 7.2 million [[Ukrainian hryvnia]] ([[United States dollar|US$]]1.42 million; [[Euro|€]]1.18 million) in compensation to the families, and Yegorov 2.5 million hryvnia. The crew's main flight trainer was acquitted for lack of evidence.[http://edition.cnn.com/2005/WORLD/europe/06/24/ukraine.airshow/ ''CNN news report, 24 June 2005''] (after the verdict)[http://www.avweb.com/avwebflash/leadnews/190074-1.html ''Aviation Web news report, 29 June 2005''] (after the verdict) After the verdict was announced, Toponar said that he planned to appeal, insisting that the crash was due to technical problems and a faulty flight plan. Yegorov was released in 2008 after President Yushchenko issued a decree reducing his sentence to three and a half years.{{cite news| url=http://www.ukrweekly.com/archive/pdf3/2012/The_Ukrainian_Weekly_2012-34.pdf | title=Lviv area residents remember Sknyliv air show disaster of 2002 | date=19 August 2012}} The pilots were assigned the majority of the blame, which included accusations of attempting maneuvers with which they were not experienced. Toponar had requested an additional training flight at the airfield where the display was to be performed; this request was denied.[http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/200208/08/eng20020808_101150.shtml ''People's Daily'' news report, 8 August 2002] (12 days after the accident) == See also == * [[Lists of air show accidents and incidents]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{ru icon}} [http://www.obozrevatel.com/news/2006/1/27/83579.htm ''Prosecution's Aerobatics After the Sknyliv Tragedy''] (2006 journalist investigation of the accident, includes photos of the crash moment) * {{uk icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20070311113059/http://www.zn.kiev.ua/nn/show/404/35672/ 2004 Article in Ukrainian ''Dzerkalo Tyznhya'' weekly] * [http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2002/07/28/1027497446606.html Sydney Morning Herald article] * [http://archives.cnn.com/2002/WORLD/europe/07/28/ukraine.detained/index.html CNN article] {{Lviv-related topics}} {{Aviation accidents and incidents in 2002}} {{coord|49|49|N|23|57|E|region:UA-46_type:landmark_scale:20000|display=title}} [[Category:Aviation accidents and incidents at air shows]] [[Category:Accidents and incidents involving military aircraft]] [[Category:Ukrainian Air Force]] [[Category:History of Lviv]] [[Category:Aviation accidents and incidents in 2002]] [[Category:Aviation accidents and incidents in Ukraine]] [[Category:2002 in Ukraine]] [[Category:July 2002 events in Europe]]
